Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

On the nomination of the Board of Home Missions
of the United Church of Canada the Department has
appointed Miss Merle W. Keyser as teacher of the junior
room at the Port Simpson Indian Day School. As recommended
in your letter of August 8 salary will be allowed her at
the rate of $95 a teaching month, plus bonus. You should
have her complete the necessary documents as soon as she
begins duties and these forms should reach us by
September 10 at the latest. As you know, we require
these in order to decide on the amount of income tax
deductions. If the forms do not reach us by the date
mentioned it will be difficult for us to have the proper
payment made to her at the end of September. What has just
been said in this regard applies to all new teachers in
British Columbia.

In the case of teachers to whom increases are
being granted, either at the school at which they were
teaching for the academic year 1943-44 or at some new
school to which they are being transferred for the
academic year 1944-45, it will be necessary to forward
new T.D. 1 forms only. These are required by the
Treasury Branch due to change in status. This applies
to all increases and transfers effective this year.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa,
August 19, 1944.

Ottawa, July 5, 1946.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, British Columbia.

I desire to refer you to official letter of
July 21, 1945, with regard to the appointment of Miss Ethel
Eileen Eason as teacher of the Port Simpson Indian Day
School. She appeared to be well qualified and we were hopeful
that her services would be satisfactory.

I am just in receipt of the following report from
Indian Agent Anfield, regarding her:

"Cleanliness of school most unsatisfactory.
This teacher's services should be dispensed with
without delay. The room is so dirty that it actually
smells,- ventilation apparently being an unknown
quality. The register had not been marked for
a month."

The Agent also reports unfavourably on the work of
Miss A. Currie, teacher of the senior room.

Both the above teachers were recommended by the
Board of Home Missions, United Church of Canada, and, while
Indian Agent Anfield considers that their services have not
been satisfactory, it is possible that they might do better
work at some other Indian day school conducted under the
auspices of the United Church of Canada.

I would appreciate it if you would discuss this
matter with Reverend Mr. Bunt and let me know what can be done.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
3861 West 14th Ave.,
Vancouver, B.C.
June 25, 1946.

L.W. McCutcheon,
Chief Treasury Officer,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

With reference to your letter file no.
168-2-1, dated June 16, 1942.

In the last paragraph, you stated that you had requested the Finance Department to issue me a cheque for the amount at my credit in the Retirement Fund.

Will you please check with your records to see if this cheque was forwarded to me? I do not remember receiving it. Shortly after your letter was written to me I enlisted in the RCAF, and had the cheque been sent to my home, it would have been forwarded. As I said, I do not think that I received it.

As I taught in the Port Simpson School from October 1940 to June 1941 (9 months) and from October 1941 to February 1942 (5 months) I should have a total of $70.00 to my credit in the Fund.

Thank you.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs Branch,

Herewith quarterly report of the Agent, Bella Coola Indian Agency, also administering the Skeena River Agency, for the period ending June 30th, 1946.

EDUCATION:- Skeena River Agency; schools were inspected at Port Simpson and Kitkathla. At Simpson there should be a change of teachers this fall. At Kitkathla there should be a two room school and a detailed report on this has reached the Department. The situation at the Crosby Girls Home at Fort Simpson is difficult but it is recommended that the school be re-opened next term, and a new staff appointed. Schools at Gitlakdami, Greenville, Kincolith and Essington appear to have functioned with satisfaction. The seasonal school at Sunnyside is being kept open through the summer. The one room school at Port Edwards will become a two room school this fall. The Great need is for a Departmental Inspector to co-ordinate and supervise the schools. Agents have not the time required to do this work in a worthwhile manner.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.

Dear Major MacKay; Re Indian Day Schools

Re Port Simpson: Following our conversation by telephone I beg to advise that Miss A. H. Currie, presently teaching the senior room in the above school has asked for transfer to another school at the end of the present term. The Agent, Mr. Anfield, has written urging that she be given another school. There is therefore no doubt that her formal resignation will be forthcoming, if it is not already in the Agent's hands. I have therefore written to Dr. Dorey, asking him to nominate, for the vacancy created by Miss Currie's resignation, Mrs. Ethel G. Castleman, who, for the past year has been teaching at Aiyansh. In view of her recent appointment, you will have all particulars regarding her qualifications.

I have wired Miss Currie, offering to nominate her for the senior room at Kispiox, and have asked her to wire her acceptance. On receipt of same I shall forward it to our Toronto office and at the same time inform you of what has been done.

Re Cape Mudge: Miss Jean Hill, presently teaching at Koksilah, is, as you know, ready to return to the Cape Mudge School, and I wish to advise you that her transfer will meet with the approval of the United Church of Canada. I have advised Dr. Dorey accordingly, but in this case, understand that any further action, making the transfer effective, will be taken by you and the Agents concerned.

Re Koksilah: In view of the pending vacancy at Koksilah, I have asked Dr. Dorey to place before your Department the name of Mrs. D.J. Miller, 727 W. 17th Ave., Vancouver, with a view to her being appointed as from January 1st, 1947. As she is a former teacher in the Koksilah School, you will be in possession of all particulars which you require. I understand that she gave good satisfaction when she was the teacher of this school.

Trusting that these nominations and transfers may have your approval.

W.P. Bunt.
Mrs. Castleman will likely fit in well at Port Simpson School and it is recommended that she be allowed salary at the rate of $118.00 a teaching month as quarters are provided.

Miss Hill applied for a transfer to the Cape Mudge School on the condition that her salary would not be less than she is receiving at the present time, but as furnished quarters and fuel are provided it is felt that her salary should not exceed $118.00 a teaching month. Miss Hill is a well qualified teacher and has given good service. Her salary should be reviewed by Mr. Davey with a view to an increase.

Mrs. Miller who rendered good service during her employment as teacher at Koksilah should be allowed the same salary as Miss Hill is now receiving at that school.

Ottawa, December 2, 1947.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, British Columbia.

Port Simpson Indian Day School

In Mr. Indian Agent Anfield's report for the month of October upon his visit to the above Indian Day School, he makes the following comments:

"The teachers are having janitor troubles, the man presently engaged having quit. It is considered that the sum of $12.00 paid per month is quite insufficient for a school of this size, involving the care of a furnace, cleaning of two rooms and extensive halls as well as the emptying of toilet pails. The Council was instructed to see that a proper janitor was appointed at once. The toilets were emptied and the teachers instructed to lock them until a proper janitor was obtained. It is recommended that at least $25.00 a month will have to be paid to get a suitable worker for the janitory of this school. By comparison, it should be said that the janitor of the adjacent white school is paid $15.00 a month. It is a small one room school with only nine pupils. The question of opening a third room at this school must be faced immediately. The senior room is overcrowded and the Principal instructed to move half of Grade III group to the junior room as a temporary measure. If all the junior grade children enrolled were present a third teacher will be needed at once. This room would be set up in the Annex, which was carefully painted and set up this summer. Only blackboards and cupboards, plus teacher's desk will be needed as additional equipment."
We are prepared to consider the payment of the janitor on the basis of $12.00 per classroom for a two-room school at Port Simpson. It is felt that you will wish to make a specific recommendation concerning Mr. Anfield's proposal regarding the third classroom.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Nov. 21, 1947.

F. E. Anfield, Esq., Indian Agent, Prince Rupert, B.C.

Re: Port Simpson Day School

With reference to your letter of November 7th, file 2-11-4, regarding the proposed purchase of an oil heater for the above mentioned school, the Department in a recent communication has intimated that the funds available in the Education Vote are almost exhausted and only the most urgent expenditures can be approved. Apart from this, however, I am not convinced that the Department should supply an oil heater for this school.

It is my understanding that the classroom and teacherage are heated from a central furnace in which case it would appear that some adjustment to the heating system should ensure reasonable heat to the teacherage during periods when the classroom is closed without excessive fuel consumption.

I note your statement that neither teacher is willing nor capable of handling the furnace themselves but would point out that although the Department provides fuel and accommodation for the teachers they are not responsible for maintaining heat in the teacherage and if the teachers are unable to look after the furnace themselves over weekend periods they should employ someone to do so at their own expense.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
November 18, 1947.

F. E. Anfield, Esq., Indian Agent, Prince Rupert, B.C.

Your report for the month of October, 1947, for the Port Simpson Indian Day School has been drawn to the attention of Inspector Davey, who has made the following observations:

1. The report shows that the number who should be attending is 53, 34 shown in the senior room and 19 in the junior room. This number does not warrant the employment of a third teacher. In the Provincial schools, the enrolment must exceed 70 before an additional teacher will be appointed. However, for a village the size of Port Simpson, it would appear that the number of 53 who should attend is an error.

2. The report indicates almost twice as many pupils in the senior room as in the junior, and it is probable that there should be some redistribution of the Grades in order to equalize the teaching load.

The Inspector has further suggested that you be asked to confirm the number of pupils who should actually be attending the Day School. He states that it will be difficult to secure the services of an additional teacher at this time but anticipates there will be no difficulty during the summer in securing a teacher for next year.

It is noted you recommend that the sum of $25.00 per month be provided for janitor services, and it is assumed that this will be the subject of separate correspondence.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

RFD/AC
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa

Re: Port Simpson Indian Day School

I wish to refer to Mr. Neary's letter of December 2nd (file 168-2-1 WT) wherein he quotes from "Mr. Indian Agent Anfield's report for the month of October covering his visit to the Port Simpson Indian Day School.

A copy of the report referred to was received at this office and I wrote to the Agent on November 18th, a copy of my letter being attached for your information. Also attached is a copy of my letter of November 21st to Mr. Anfield in response to his request for the supply of an oil heater for the Port Simpson Day School teacherage. I have not yet received a reply to either of these communications and would prefer not to make a recommendation with respect to the revision of the rate for janitor services until I do.

D. V. Mackay,

Director of handicrafts,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Dear Madam:

Would you kindly let me know what service or advice you are prepared to give to establish handicrafts at Fort Simpson Reserve.

We are doing what we can to develop woodworking and home-nursing within the school curriculum, but I am interested in what has been done in similar cases for avocational or pastime projects among young people or even with older persons who have time on their hands—as most of these people have.

We now have a projector and would be able to show craft or handcraft films, such as "The Hand Is Sure", or films that would promote horticultural pursuits or the keeping of small farm animals.

We would therefore be glad to be advised by you on this matter also.

Sincerely yours,

A.D. Flowers,
Principal,
Indian Day School,
Fort Simpson, B.C.

Department of Indian Affairs
OTTAWA, 26th February, 1900

The Secretary:

Rev. Dr Sutherland writes under date of the 21st instant asking that provision may be made in the Supplementary estimates for money to put up a new day school building at Port Simpson to cost from $1000 to $1200.

He states that he is informed that owing to a new survey of the village, the present school building is found to be in the middle of the street and will have to be moved, which Mr Osterhout thinks could not be done with safety, at least without going to very great expense.

The Department contributed $500 towards the cost of the present building in 1882 and I think before moving it or putting up another one, Mr Vowell should be asked to report in regard to this matter, which could be allowed to stand until next year's estimates as there need not be any great hurry for opening up the street. The survey was made about three years ago but the field notes are not on file in the office and the plan does not show where the school building stands.

The census gives the population of Port Simpson as 680, which would give about 150 children of
of school age and the attendance at this school been over 100 for some quarters.

If it is found necessary to rebuild, it would require quite a large school to accommodate all these children.

Five hundred and sixty of the inhabitants of Port Simpson are given as Methodists, and as I said on my memorandum on file 77,025, that denomination is conducting three schools there, two boarding and one day, and I have no doubt but that the boarders attend the day school, to which all the children might go, boarding school provision being necessary only for orphans and children of that class. The Port Simpson Indians are well to do and should be able to provide for the maintenance of their own families.

Martin Brown

Sir,

In a letter recently received from the Rev S.S. Osterhout, of Port Simpson, B.C., he informs me that owing to a new survey of the village (or part of it) ordered by the Indian Agent, the public school building will be left standing in the middle of a new street. This would indicate, of course, the necessity of moving the school building to a new site. But Mr Osterhout is of opinion that the condition of the building is such that it cannot be safely moved, at least without great expense, and suggests whether it would not be better and cheaper in the end to erect a new building. In view of the number of children of school age at Port Simpson it is probable that a fairly good building, large enough for the purpose, would cost from $1000 to $1200. Dr Sutherland in February last for provision to be made in the Supplementary Estimates for the erection of a new day school building at Fort Simpson I beg to say that Mr Supt. Vowell who was written to for a report in this matter has replied under date of the 30th ultimo recommending that the suggestions of Mr Agent Todd for the erection of a new school house be carried out.

Mr Agent Todd's report is placed herewith and in it he states that it will be necessary to have a new building within a very short time, as the site where the old building stands is required for other purposes, and as the old building will not stand removal it will have to be taken down and a new one put up, but that a considerable portion of the material in the old building can be used in the new one, thus reducing the cost of material and labor to about $3000, which sum he considers would be sufficient, and he furnishes an estimate in support of his figures. Mr Todd states in his report that the present building might last a year or two more, but that it must ere long be removed so as not to retard the completion of the arrangements of the streets according to the new survey.
Of the Department decides to contribute towards the erection of the new building, I think it would be time enough to give a grant next year when funds could be provided in the main estimates and Dr Sutherland and Mr Vowell might be so advised.

Port Simpson, B. C., January 23rd, 1904.

Geo. W. Morrow, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Metlakatla, B. C.

Dear Sir:

Whereas the building now occupied by the Port Simpson Indian Day School is no longer fit for use, being greatly out of repair, the roof leaking badly, the front approach gone, the front porch sunken on its foundations, the foundation of the main building rotting owing to the bad location of the building, the floors worn out, and the place being totally without out-houses of any description;

And whereas, owing to the condition of the building, as also to the undesirableness of its present location, the ground being very wet and boggy, making it unwholesome for the children as well as ruinous to the building, we deem it unwise to expend the considerable sum now required for repairs on the old building; and in this we think that you, sir, having inspected the place, will agree with us;

And whereas the attendance at the school is large, there now being nearly eighty pupils enrolled on the register, which attendance is sometimes increased to about a hundred by the pupils of a neighboring institution, and two teachers are usually employed in the building;

And whereas the present building was erected without any aid from the Indian Department;

And whereas such a building as is specified in the accompanying plan and estimates is the cheapest kind of building which will adequately meet the requirements of the place, viz., a main building twenty four by forty feet ground measurements, with fourteen foot posts, fronted by a porch ten feet square, and having at the rear a wing twenty by thirty two feet, opening into the main building by sliding doors, the building to be covered with rustic nailed on ship-lap, and ceiled inside with four inch v siding, and at the rear of the wing a fuel shed ten by sixteen feet, and two water closets eight feet square, separated by a tight board fence eight feet high and thirty feet long;

And whereas the Mission will undertake the erection of the new building without further cost to the Department, provided the Department cause to be placed on the ground the required material;

And whereas the Georgetown Saw Mill Company of Port Simpson has peculiar facilities in the shape of saw-mill, steamboat, etc., for undertaking the contract to supply the material to better advantage than anyone else we know of;

And whereas the said Company submit herewith tender to place on the ground the required material detailed in the accompanying specifications for the sum of thirteen hundred and ten dollars;

We therefore humbly request that the Indian Department make grant of that amount for such purpose.

And ever we will pray.

Your humble petitioner,

B. C. Greenan
Dept. of Revenue

OTTAWA, 9th March, 1904:

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Mr. Supt. Vowell encloses an application from Rev. P.C. Froemen, Supt. of Methodist Missions at Fort Simpson, asking for a grant of $1309.92 for the purchase of material to erect a new Indian day school building at that place. Mr. Agent Morrow of Metlakatla recommends this application in view of the large number of children in attendance and the dilapidated condition of the present building.

This application is a renewal of one made four years ago for the same purpose which reached the Department through the General Secretary of the Methodist Missionary Society. As Mr. Sifton was then absent the matter was laid over.

The Indians resident in Fort Simpson by the last census number 718, all of whom are Methodists and the school population is given as 127. The enrollment last year was 79. At the time the first application was made the present building was said to be in bad condition and its situation interfered with the proper laying out of the main street. Four years ago the Church would have been satisfied with $1000.00 but the larger amount now asked for is probably due to the increase in the cost of material.

In addition to the day school the Methodists carry on two boarding schools in the village, one for
boys and one for girls, which receive a grant for 10 and 20 pupils respectively at $60.00 each.

It would appear that a new day school building is required and it is a question to what extent the Department is willing to contribute. The sketch prepared by the missionary provides for two class-rooms with seating accommodation for 80 pupils. Outbuildings are also included.

I have turned out my previous memoranda on this subject.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, 24th February, 1905.

The Deputy Asst. General,

I have carefully gone over plans and bill of quantities for the proposed school at Fort Simpson, and find that materials proposed to be used are sufficient and of the right dimensions, with a few exceptions.

I would recommend that 2" x 8" be used for ceiling joists, as 2" x 6", 30' long are not strong enough, and there is no way of bracing to support the same, without using more timber, than in thus increasing the size of joists; also that 2 X 6 rafter and ceiling joists be used for porch instead of 2 X 4", as specified. The change suggested would require 428 feet, at 2 cents per foot—$8.56

There has been no provision made for window glass, thirty-six windows, with four lights of 15" x 36" would cost glazed, probably, $64. It will be necessary to add these amounts to the bill of quantities, making the amount $1,850.75, instead of $1,778.19.

There are no specifications supplied, and the plan is a very crude one. It would be necessary to have plans and specifications furnished for filing with the Department, and will also require additional supervision to ensure proper construction, when plans and specifications are so limited as those now submitted.

Respectfully submitted,

My fellow teacher, Miss Perry, and I strongly recommend that a teacherage be provided.

This last year the problem of suitable boarding accommodation has caused me much thought, worry, and trouble.

Before Xmas, Miss Perry boarded with one family and I boarded with the minister's family. I was very happy and lived just two doors away from the school.

When Miss Perry and I were home for Xmas, the minister's wife died and I was informed that I was to board at the same place as Miss Perry, as it was the only available place.

Before long both Miss Perry and I became displeased with our accommodation, as we were not pleased with our food, etc., and considered the price too high. We asked for a reduction in price but were refused, so decided to find a new place.

None of the "white" families could take us so we had to make plans accordingly. Miss Perry now "boards" with another teacher, quite near the school, while I board with a quarter-breed family, who live off the reserve, about a mile from the school. We are both very pleased with...
our present living conditions.

However, in the coming years, I suggest that it would be better if a suitable boarding house or teachers' quarters could be provided. For them the teachers could be together and would not be constantly on the move.

Hoping that this suggestion will bear a little consideration,

Sincerely yours,

Dear Mr. Beaton:

For some time now, there has been an agitation afoot in our village for a new Indian Day School. The Indian Agent has been approached from various directions, and by various individuals. I have broached the subject myself. To date we have received no encouragement from the Indian Department.

We are all agreed that the present building is in a deplorable condition, and, as I stated in one of my monthly reports to the Indian Agent, is a public disgrace to the community and the Government of Canada.

No repairs have been done on the building for years. Last year I requisitioned for paint for the inside of the school, but it was not forthcoming. This year, I have decided that the building is not worth repairs or paint. Some months ago the Village Council appointed a committee of three of their best carpenters to examine the foundations of the school building and report what they found.

This week that report was made by Thomas Gosness, who says that the foundation is a foot lower at one corner, and that a very high wind might send the building over at any time. One of the first things I learned about the building, when I came two years ago, was that the upper room was condemned for the use of a crowd as unsafe. It was considered dangerous to take a class of children up there for physical exercises, - Mr. Gosnell told me that himself, and I am told that Captain Barry condemned the building on one of his visits. At the time of our Christmas entertainment, we considered using the upper room, and were told that it was unsafe, that a hundred people in the upper room might collapse the building. That was eighteen months ago, now it is considered that nowhere is it secure in a high wind.

Apart from the fact that the foundations are not safe, and the building is antiquated from the standpoint of heating and lighting, the sanitary conditions of a school that has an attendance of between ninety and a hundred are, to say the least, outrageous, partly due to the antiquity and inadequacy of such necessary facilities, and partly due to the fact that the teachers get little or no support from the Indian Department, in the matter of essential repairs to be made from time to time.

I think that the Indian Department would be well-advised to, at least, make its own investigation of the matter, for conditions are of late rapidly growing worse.

Yours truly,

Signed - Frances L. Patterson.

I have your letter of the 10th instant, addressed to Mr. Sutherland, of this Department, regarding the necessity for the erection of a new day school building at Port Simpson.

Dear Sir:

Re: Indian Day School, Fort Simpson, B.C.

The Port Simpson Indian Council has inspected the Indian Day School in this village and has found the building unsafe and unsanitary. The roof at the centre of the ridge sags about one foot. The long walls of the building bulge to the same extent. The corners of the building are opening. And the foundation is gone in several places.

Besides these fundamental matters the building is in general poor repair. The siding is loose and falling off also many of the windows are broken and the problem of keeping the place dry and warm is becoming a greater one. In stormy weather many of the parents refuse to send their children to school. Added to this the toilet system is a decided health menace.

In view of all these facts the Council in session on December 11th decided that the school should remain closed until action is taken by the authorities to provide for safe and sanitary accommodation for pupils and teachers.

The teachers of the school have been notified of the action of the Council and a notice has been posted on the door of the building.

Yours truly,

The Port Simpson Indian Council.

Dear Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a letter, signed by P. M. Wells, Secretary of the Port Simpson Indian Council, in which he states that the members of the Council recently inspected the Port Simpson Indian Day School and that, at their meeting on the 11th instant, they decided that the school should remain closed until action is taken to provide better accommodation. He further states that the teachers of the school have been notified of the motion of the Council and that a notice has been posted on the door of the building.

While the Department is aware that a new building is required to replace the present Port Simpson Day School, at the same time, the Indian Council has no right to notify the teachers to discontinue duties. I would appreciate your advising me, at once, whether or not the two teachers of this school closed the school or whether it is to be re-opened on the 4th proximo.

The necessity for a new building has been carefully considered by the Department but it is regretted that, owing to lack of funds, it is not possible, at the present time, to state definitely when a new school can be erected. Port Simpson is not the only point that requires a new building. At several other places in Canada, new schools are necessary but, as the funds placed at our disposal are not sufficient to permit construction to proceed, the present buildings will have to be used until financial conditions warrant increased expenditure. You should point out to the Indians that the delay in providing a new building at Port Simpson is not due to neglect on the part of the Department but simply due to the fact that the money for the purpose could not be secured.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

No doubt the Department will also wish to have the Church authorities consulted with in this connection, inasmuch as the property and building are somewhat involved in recognized jurisdiction. Memorandum: The Acting Deputy Minister.

It has been reported to the department that the Indian Bay School at Fort Simpson has been closed due to the fact that it is unsafe. The building is very old and it is stated that it would not be practical or advisable to carry out any repairs. It is recommended that a new two classroom day school be erected immediately, same to be constructed by day labour under the supervision of a competent working foreman, and employment given to as many Indians as possible in its erection.

Owing to the location of the proposed school it is rather difficult to make an accurate estimate of the cost, but it is considered that $6,000 will provide for its erection. Funds are available in Vote 518, Special Supplementary Estimates.

If you approve it will be necessary to commence operations immediately and I would ask for the name of a competent foreman to be employed to supervise the work and to engage whatever additional white labour he requires outside of Indian labour. The Indian Agent will decide what Indians are to be given employment on the work.

I would also ask to be furnished with the names of firms in Prince Rupert where the materials may be purchased. These materials will consist principally of lumber, millwork, cement, hardware and paint.

The existing school is situated approximately 35 miles from Prince Rupert by boat and it is proposed to erect the new school on the same site, using as much material from the old building as can be salvaged.

The Indian Bay School at Fort Simpson is located in the electoral district of Sheena.

Director of Indian Affairs.
Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated Dec. 29th last, No.158-2-5, relative to the Port Simpson Indian Day School, which was received on my return on the 13th Jan., from the Queen Charlotte Islands.

In this connection, I would confirm my telegram to the Department of the 13th as follows—

"Reference Port Simpson day school closed by village council without authority (stop) recommend competent builder inspect building and report cost and necessity temporary repairs (stop) At present pupils not attending and teachers unoccupied (stop) Kindly wire authorizing same as immediate action advisable."

Needless to say, the action of the Port Simpson council in closing the school was entirely unauthorized, and I have my suspicions that the whole thing was prompted by parties interested in having a new school.

Whilst the building is no doubt old, I am of the opinion that a few repairs would tide over the present situation and as stated in a letter to the Commissioner at Victoria, and in my telegram to the Department, would recommend that an independent inspection of the building be made to determine the present condition of the structure. Although both teachers are on the spot, the pupils have so far not attended and have no doubt been influenced by their parents in this regard.

With regard to the site of the present building it is, I understand, Indian reserve which was handed over by the Indians for the temporary use
of the Methodist Church in 1917 for church and educational purposes. (Kindly refer to official letter 119542-1, dated April 17th 1917)

As to the building itself, there appears to be considerable doubt as to ownership, and it may be that the Department gave a grant in aid at the time of its erection as the upper storey of the building was for some years used for various meetings and classes in connection with the church.

The Indian Council has been notified of the Department's decision in the matter and as soon as a reply has been received to my telegram, I shall know how to proceed.

Sir:

With further reference to the Fort Simpson day school, I would state that I visited the reserve on the 21st inst. and inspected the school which is a two-storey building over 30 years old.

While the foundation is in fair condition, the principal weakness at present lies in the roof which has sagged considerably tending to force out the walls. Any extra weight such as a heavy fall of snow might further endanger the building. I arranged to have temporary buttresses set up against the building on both sides and supports placed under the roof which should strengthen the building for the time being.

I would not advise the Department to go to further expense in connection with the old building and would recommend that a new up to date school be constructed suitable for the needs of the village.

It has been suggested that the proposed new school should be erected on a new site away from the present mission reserve. I am in favor of this as the new situation will provide a better playground for the pupils and being more accessible to the waterfront, better sanitary arrangements can be provided.

I do not consider it possible to complete the building before the end of the present fiscal year as it will be the end of February at least before actual construction can be started.

The type of school required will be a two-
room building—preferably three, as the attendance in the junior room is sometimes more than one teacher can handle. Accommodation should be provided for at least 100 pupils, and the building provided with necessary conveniences such as central heating, cloak rooms, wash rooms and outside toilets for boys and girls.

The question of suitable accommodation for the teachers has always been a source of dissatisfaction, and I would suggest, if possible, that suitable living quarters for the two permanent teachers be attached to the school. Should a third teacher be required any time, accommodation can be obtained elsewhere.

In view of the difficulties and delays we have experienced in connection with the building of the new Kitselas school, I would strongly urge that the building of the Fort Simpson school be placed in the hands of a reliable building firm by contract.

In order to provide for the future it may be advisable to increase the accommodation to 125 pupils as the population of Port Simpson has increased during the last few years.

I shall be glad to receive complete plans and specifications for the new building together with the Department's instructions.

Dear Sir:

The subject matter of your letter of the 27th ultimo has been given careful consideration by the departmental officials, and the suggestions you make have been carefully noted.

I am deeply interested in vocational instruction, and I should like to see greater provision made for such instruction in any schools we may decide to erect during the period that may lie ahead of us. With this thought in mind, I have suggested to the Architect that we might consider the advisability of constructing a day school at Fort Simpson, specially designed for manual training. I have in mind a school with two classrooms, capable of accommodating 40 pupils in each room; and, in addition, a smaller room, designed to give girls a certain amount of instruction in elementary domestic science. I am of the opinion, also, that accommodation should be provided for two teachers. I have been wondering if it would be possible to obtain enough material from the old building to erect a workshop for boys, adjoining the main building. I beg to report as follows for the month of January.

PORT SIMPSON SCHOOL

On Thursday, the 22nd inst., a special trip was made to Port Simpson to look into the school situation there.

Following a meeting with the village council, and accompanied by some of the members, an inspection was made of the school building. As a result, temporary repairs were arranged for and the building braced pending the Department's decision regarding the erection of a new school. I pointed out to the Council that they had exceeded their rights in closing the school, and was assured that the council's action was taken solely to safeguard the children as it was feared a heavy fall of snow might greatly endanger the building.

Had I not been absent from the agency at the time, matters would have been speedily adjusted and there would have been no need of closing the school. The letter signed by the council was no doubt written by a white resident and that they did not realize the peremptory tone of the communication.

W. E. Collison,
Indian Agent.

MEMORANDUM:

MR. PRATT.

Re Fort Simpson Day School.

As you are aware, the Department gave some consideration to the erection of a new building, but after correspondence with the Agent it was found that even though construction started it could not be completed before the end of the present fiscal year. In addition, there was some doubt as to the amount of funds that could be secured for the purpose.

In the Special Supplementary Estimates requested for the fiscal year 1937-38 provision has been made for a new school, at an approximate cost of $7,500.

If this amount is allowed, and before work proceeds, the matter will, no doubt, be brought to the attention of your office by our Architect. It should be possible to arrange to have the building erected by day labour in charge of a competent foreman, in which event the gentleman whose name has been brought to your attention could be engaged.

Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter dated Feb. 11th, relative to the proposed day school for the Fort Simpson village, I believe in my previous letter it was stated that it would be necessary to provide for 125 pupils; but as there are 75 names enrolled, I am of the opinion that accommodation should be provided for 100, in order to take care of any future increase, my first figure being based on the increase in population on this reserve.

The addition of a room for domestic science teaching is I think, a good idea, provided that the services of a domestic science teacher is obtained. With such large classes it would be impossible for the other teachers to take up this subject.

It will be possible to obtain sufficient lumber from the old building for the erection of a workshop. If this is done, I would suggest that the manual training be started on a small scale. The Indians are handy with the use of tools and frequently have the idea that they know everything.

They nearly all have some knowledge of gas engines as they own their own fishing boats many of which have been built by themselves, and the boys are accustomed at an early age to handle their boats. With this in view I would suggest that unless a qualified instructor is appointed to teach these subjects the scheme may not meet with the success warranted by a large outlay. Personally, I am strongly in favor of vocational training but consider it advisable that the scheme be tried out gradually before any large expense is incurred.

I would also suggest that a covered shelter, or shed, be erected for use during recess in bad weather.
The Indians have set apart two vacant lots for the school, but in order to guard against fire hazard, it is advisable that twenty-five feet of each of the adjoining occupied lots, numbers Two and One, should be purchased by the Department. This could be done for the sum of $50.00 ($25.00 each).

The accommodation for the two teachers is particularly desirable.

If central heating is planned a larger appropriation will be required to cover this extra cost.

I am enclosing a sketch of the proposed site with the information asked for by Mr. Orr, and shall await the Department's instructions with regard to the commencement of the work on the building.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

WEC/JJ

Indian Agent

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs, branch
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Memorandum:

May I direct your attention to a letter, dated March 3rd, received from Mr. W. E. Collison, Indian Agent, Prince Rupert, B. C. This letter was written in response to our request for additional information in respect to the construction of a day school at Fort Simpson.

In my judgment, we should proceed with the construction of a day school, consisting of two main classrooms capable of accommodating 40 pupils, each; a smaller room, sufficiently spacious to give instruction in elementary domestic science to groups of girls (25 to 30); and a residence for two teachers. I am convinced, also, that we can very profitably use the material in the old school for the construction of an additional workshop, in which vocational instruction can be provided for boys. Dear Sir:

The plans of the new Indian day school for Port Simpson have been received at this office. They have been looked over by Inspector Barry, who is now visiting in this agency, and myself, and in this connection I should like to point out:

1. That no provision has been made for an inside bathroom and toilet for the teacher's residence, and no outside toilets for the school.

2. That platforms have been provided for both class rooms.

3. That blackboard space has only been provided at one end of each class room.

4. That no provision has been made for washrooms for either boys or girls.

With regard to provision for a bathroom, I would point out that it is absolutely necessary that one should be installed for the convenience of the teachers. In this connection, it will be necessary to provide a sewer pipe from the school to the beach, a distance of approximately one hundred yards, with a good fall towards the sea. This will entail sewer pipe and the digging of a shallow ditch to low water mark.

I am informed by Inspector Barry that class room platforms are unnecessary. Such platforms were used in the past, but have been discontinued in all British Columbia schools for a considerable time. Teacher's desks are not now placed actually at the end
of a classroom, but diagonally across one corner, this is recognized as the best position for the teacher's desk. Similar platforms as those indicated on the plans have been removed from a number of our Indian schools in the past.

With respect to blackboard space, it is considered by the Inspector and myself that additional blackboard should be placed in each class room along the whole length of the dividing wall opposite the windows as well as at the end of the class room. The provision for blackboard space as is now suggested is a feature of all modern class room construction. It is necessary that every facility should be afforded the Indian children for blackboard writing and other related work.

With regard to wash room accommodation, it is hardly necessary to point out the absolute necessity for such accommodation in any modern Indian school. In view of the fact that no provision has been made on the ground floor, it is suggested that possibly the necessary wash rooms could be arranged for in the basement, or if this is considered impracticable, wash basins with water connections might be installed in the corridor on the ground floor.

The Fort Simpson Indian Council are installing an electric lighting plant for the village which will be of sufficient capacity to supply public buildings on the reserve, and it might be advisable to wire the teachers' residence and school for this purpose as the use of electric light is much safer than coal oil lamps which would otherwise be used in the building.
These matters are being brought to the attention of the Department at the present time in order to save the extra expense that would be involved in rectifying such omissions at a later date.

It is to be regretted that a copy of the school plans was not forwarded to this office at an earlier date so that suggestions could have been made before work commenced on the building.

Yours faithfully,

Indian Agent

Dear Sir,

Having just returned from a visit to Fort Simpson I beg leave to place before you some of my findings in regard to the new school building now being constructed by the Government for that village.

As you may know the old school building became very dilapidated and has been used to date by being propped up with heavy timbers to strengthen it in times of storm. The new building was sorely needed and is rapidly taking shape, the workers being engaged with the plastering of the building when I visited the same. The two class rooms I think will be most suitable for the purposes.

The matter I wish particularly to bring to your attention is that while the building is costing a considerable sum of money - approximately $4,000.00 - there is no provision whatever made for bathroom and toilet accommodation, neither for the two-room school or for the two teachers employed in the work there. This surely must be an oversight on the part of the Government or the Contractors who have had the erection of the building in hand. As the building is still uncompleted I think it is not too late to make a constructive suggestion in regard to this most important and urgent matter.

The accommodation for the teachers consists of two large bedrooms upstairs and a kitchen and living room downstairs. In addition to that there is a room designated for the purpose of Domestic Science teaching, which is perhaps not urgently needed at the moment, at least not so urgently required as the accommodation I have referred to. My suggestion therefore is that the room set apart for Domestic Science be devoted to bathroom and toilet requirements, with entrances off the hall for class-room purposes, one for the boys and one for girls and a portion of the same room with entrance from the living room of the teachers for bathroom equipment for their use. I presume the Domestic Science room would be sufficiently large for such accommodation. The equipment required might possibly cost a little more than that for domestic science, but it seems to me that the same is so imperative that any additional expense involved in the alteration I am suggesting would be money well spent if indeed it is necessary to make any additional grant for the purpose.
The building is very nicely located on the street leading up from the wharf and the Hudson's Bay Co., and faces on property still belonging to that Company which I have no doubt may be used for an unlimited time by the children as a playground, a most desirable acquisition to the school and made possible by the happy location of the building.

Trusting that my suggestion will be welcomed by your department and that I may be favoured with your reaction to the proposal at your own convenience,

I remain,

Very sincerely yours,

[Signature]

SSO/AM
Dear Sir:

I am forwarding the enclosed letter received from the Reverend S. S. Osterhout, Superintendent of Indian Missions of the United Church of Canada, regarding the new Indian Day School on the Port Simpson Indian Reserve, in the Skeena Agency.

The attention of the Department is called to Indian Agent Collison's letter dated 26th October, 1937, his file 2-E-11138, in which certain recommendations were made before work was actually started on the superstructure of the building. In view of the fact that the building is now nearing completion, the recommendations made by Dr. Osterhout would involve considerable additional expense.

The matter has been discussed with Inspector Barry who agrees with Dr. Osterhout's contention, but suggests that the room intended for a domestic science class be divided into two parts; one to be equipped as toilet and bathroom for use of the teachers; while the other part might well be equipped as a children's washroom. It is suggested that the available village water supply, though not abundant, might be installed in this room.

It is not considered advisable to have the boys' and girls' toilets on the main floor of the School and in near proximity to the teachers' living quarters. Under the circumstances, it is recommended that separate toilets for boys and girls be erected outside of the building on the School grounds.

I may say that the plans and arrangements in connection with the construction of this School were made without reference to this Office.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, ONT.
While it would be convenient for the teachers to install a bathroom I would point out that this would involve considerable extra expense at this time but as no funds are provided for the purpose it is not possible to favourably consider Doctor Osterhout's request in this regard. The funds for the erection of the Port Simpson School were provided in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1936-37. This Vote expires on the 31st instant and no additional funds have been provided in our next year's estimates for the expenditure that would be necessary to install a bathroom.

On February 11, 1937, I wrote Indian Agent Collison with a view to ascertaining if he considered it possible to obtain enough material from the old building to erect a work shop for the boys adjoining the new school. I pointed out at that time that this building would not need to be expensive but could be equipped with benches and the equipment necessary to enable the boys to undertake carpentry work or some other branch of vocational instruction.

Mr. Collison replied to my letter in part as follows: "It will be possible to obtain sufficient lumber from the old building for the erection of a work shop. If this is done I would suggest that the manual training be started on a small scale. The Indians are handy with the use of tools but frequently have the idea that they know everything. Personally I am strongly in favour of vocational training but consider it advisable that the scheme be tried out gradually before any large expense is incurred."

I concur in what Mr. Collison said in his letter with reference to starting on a small scale and I would, therefore, appreciate if you would let me know what would be the probable cost of the erection of a small work shop for the boys using the material from the old building.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 16th instant enclosing letter received from Reverend S. S. Osterhout with reference to the new Fort Simpson Day School.

It is the Department's desire to have the instruction at Indian Day Schools as practical as possible. Consequently, when erecting new buildings it is our intention to provide facilities for the teaching of domestic science and manual training. As a result, when considering plans for the new school at Fort Simpson it was decided to provide a domestic science room and we are not prepared to make the change suggested by Reverend Mr. Osterhout. I might add that the Associate Secretary of the Board of Home Missions of the United Church of Canada was consulted at the time the plans were prepared and he fully approved our desire to provide a domestic science classroom.

For your information I may add that on the second floor of the new building there is a small room in which a chemical toilet has been installed for the use of the teachers.

If outside toilets for the pupils have not yet been provided you should ascertain from the Indian Agent if the toilets at the old school can be moved to the new site and if not you may authorize the Indian Agent to construct new outside toilets. It is understood, of course, that the cost will be kept as low as possible.

Dear Doctor Dorey:

The new Day School at Fort Simpson is practically completed and I hope that it will be ready for occupation early next month.

Provision has been made for two classrooms, also domestic science room. The following accommodation is provided for the teachers: Living room and kitchen on ground floor; two bedrooms, clothes closets and small room with chemical toilet on second floor.

You will remember that early in 1937 I discussed this school with you and that you agreed that it would be advisable to provide facilities for the teaching of domestic science. Recently I received a letter from Indian Commissioner MacKay enclosing a letter from Reverend Dr. Osterhout suggesting that the domestic science room be divided into a toilet and bathroom. You are aware of my desire to make the training at Indian Day Schools as practical as possible and it is, therefore, rather discouraging to receive a suggestion such as that made by Dr. Osterhout.

Indian Commissioner MacKay is being informed that the Department is not prepared to favourably consider Dr. Osterhout's suggestion. We are also requesting the Indian Commissioner to make inquiries with a view to using the material in the old school for a small work shop for the boys.

Rev. Geo. Dorey, D.D.,
Associate Secretary,
Board of Home Missions,
United Church of Canada,
299 Queen St. W.,
Toronto, Ont.
The completion of the new Port Simpson School raises the question of teaching services for the academic year 1938-39. Dear Sir:

In the erection of the Port Simpson Indian Day School provision was made for a vocational training room for the girls.

I would appreciate if you would discuss with Inspector Barry the equipment that should be supplied. Full particulars and estimates of the cost of the articles recommended should be forwarded in order that the information may be given to our Purchasing Agent.

In referring to vocational equipment I feel that provision should be made for sewing, knitting, crocheting, hand loom weaving, Indian handicrafts and domestic science. Dear Sir:

On March 23 last I wrote Indian Commissioner MacKay in part as follows: "If outside toilets for the pupils have not yet been provided you should ascertain from the Indian Agent if the toilets at the old school can be moved to the new site and if not you may authorize the Indian Agent to construct new outside toilets. It is understood, of course, that the cost will be kept as low as possible."

Today I am in receipt of a letter from Reverend Doctor Dorey, Associate Secretary, Board of Home Missions, United Church of Canada, who is visiting British Columbia and he states that at the time of writing these toilets had not been erected. I am, therefore, sending a telegram today to Commissioner MacKay instructing him to authorize you to proceed immediately with their construction.

As yet I have received no reply to my letter of April 23. Please let me hear from you at once.

Dear Sir:-

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letters dated April 23rd and May 12th relative to the new Day School at Port Simpson.

Owing to my absence from the office it was not possible to reply to your first letter at an earlier date.

Acting on instructions received through Indian Commissioner MacKay on May 13th, an estimate was obtained for the construction of two outside toilets. This work is now in hand. As stated in a previous letter to the Commissioner, the toilets at the old school could not be utilized as they are too ancient. The new ones are being built from lumber and material left over from the new school. This will reduce the cost considerably.

An estimate, of the cost of erecting a manual training shop, is being prepared and will be forwarded as soon as possible.

It would be inadvisable to open the new building until after the summer holidays, as most of the pupils are now away from the Village and will not return until late in September. By that time the building will be ready, and the furniture for the teachers' quarters provided and installed. I have already pointed out, in a previous communication, that the toilet arrangements for the teachers' residence is most unsatisfactory and unsanitary.

Nearly all the lumber and hardware left over from the new building, as per list supplied by the Surveys and Engineering Branch, can be used in connection with the school outhouses and manual training shop. With regard however, to the hard wall cement (72 sacks) and a quantity of plaster of paris, I inquired of the firm that supplied the cement whether they would take back the unused supply.

Dear Sir:

I have to report as follows for the month of January.

My attention was called to the unsatisfactory condition of the new day school basement which floods during wet weather, making it miserable for the teachers who have to tend the furnace. It would appear that no proper drainage system was installed round the basement walls with the result that water seeps through the walls into the furnace room and coal bin from the rear of the building. During my inspection there were four to six inches of water in the coal bin. I would recommend that this be remedied as soon as possible.

W.E. Collison,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

On receipt of your report for the month of January, I communicated with the Surveys & Engineering Branch regarding the unsatisfactory condition of the basement at the Fort Simpson Indian Day School.

With reference to this matter, I am informed as follows:

"The water table in fall and winter is practically at the surface of the ground. This necessitated digging drainage trenches up to eight or nine feet deep to carry away the water to a creek bottom 250 feet distant from the school before excavation could begin.

On account of high water table 450 feet of drain tile had to be installed to protect the basement from dampness. Later this was extended for a further 75 feet by using old water pipe from the Fort Simpson water lines."

It appears from the above that the Surveys & Engineering Branch consider that they have done everything possible to keep the basement dry. If, in view of the information regarding what has been done, you consider any further work could be carried out in order to ensure a dry basement, please let me have an estimate of the cost of what you recommend might be done to overcome the difficulty.

Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter dated March 14th last respecting drainage conditions in connection with Port Simpson Indian day school. In this matter, I have also written Mr. C.E. Webb, District Chief Engineer at Vancouver, and enclose herewith copy of my letter to him.

During my recent visit to Port Simpson I inspected the basement and drainage leading from the school to the foresnore.

I was informed by the Indian foreman, Mr. Peter Wells, who was engaged on the construction of the school that some loose rock was placed around the foot or the cement walls on the outside, these have evidently become seated in the soft muskeg. He also stated that some drainage tile had been installed. On examination of the drain pipe leading from the school, it was found clogged with lime which has prevented any drainage from the basement.

The drain pipe to the foresnore is also blocked at a point approximately 120 feet from the lower outlet, owing, as I was informed by Mr. Wells, to the fact that the extension to the 4" tile pipe consists of 2" wooden pipe, in other words, 4" tile pipe empties into 2" pipe and naturally it has become blocked at the point where the two different sizes of pipe join.

It will be necessary to take up the 2" pipe for the distance stated, and replace it with proper 4" drain tile. The upper end of the pipe should also be cleaned out, otherwise the lime will solidify and may necessitate taking up the whole line.

As stated in my letter to Mr. Webb, the work should not take longer than three days to do, employing one man and a helper; enclosed is an approximate cost of the whole undertaking.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant in which you state you are enclosing a letter from Indian Agent Gillett. However, the letter to which you refer was not received with yours.

In a letter dated December 15, 1938, Indian Agent Collison requested authority to dispose of two used stoves which had been in the junior and senior classrooms of the old Port Simpson School. He was authorized to sell these to Indians and on February 13, 1939, he remitted the amount of $17.00 and advised us that the stoves had been sold to E. Daldow and Thomas Gosnell but he did not state definitely at the time what price each of the men mentioned had paid. It appears from the second paragraph of your letter that Mr. Gosnell wishes to resell his stove to us at a cost of $10.00. As the stove was not satisfactory for use at the Port Simpson School in 1938 and has been used by Gosnell for the past three years it is extremely doubtful if it is worth $10.00 now. I presume that only a small heater is required for the manual training division of the present Port Simpson School and possibly it would be to our advantage to purchase a new stove even though it costs more than $10.00. You may make whatever arrangements you consider best in the circumstances.

Yours truly,

Dear Major MacKay:

As requested by you, I have considered with care the contents of Mr. Indian Agent Gillett's letter 2-11-2A of the 13th instant with regard to the provision of fire exit doors in the class rooms of the Port Simpson Indian Day School, Skeena River Agency.

At present, should an emergency occur, the only possible exit for the children would be through a transverse hallway, each class room opening directly onto this hall. It is, of course, through this hallway that children make their exit during fire drills.

I am inclined to agree with Mr. Gillett that better provision should be made for the safety of the children in case the school has to be evacuated or cleared in a very brief time and without the slightest chance of confusion. I would, therefore, recommend that the provision of two outside doors now asked for be favorably considered.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6408, file 837-5, part 3)
Dear Sir:

The Port Simpson Council requests that fire exit doors be placed in each class room of the Port Simpson Indian Day School. At present there is one ordinary door opening into an inside corridor from each room.

Apart from a possible emergency due to war conditions, I consider that more adequate provisions should be made for escape in case of fire. I strongly recommend that permission be given to have these arrangements made immediately, as there are a hundred pupils in this school at present.

The Council has agreed to provide the labour if the Department will supply the material which consists of the following:

- 2 outside doors @ $4.75 = $9.50
- 4 hinges @ 50¢ = $2.00
- 2 inside sliding bolts with fittings @ 60¢ = $1.20
- Door facings and jams, etc. = $8.00
- Paint and incidentals = $4.30

Total = $25.00

The prices listed are those from local firms. If these articles were purchased at Vancouver and shipped direct to Port Simpson by S.S. Catala, there would possibly be a saving of $3.00 or $4.00.

Yours faithfully,

J. Gillett
Indian Agent

Dear Sir:

With reference to the provision of fire exit doors at the Fort Simpson Indian Day School, Skeena River Agency, I am forwarding herewith a letter dated December 13th received from Mr. Indian Agent Gillett and also a letter of today's date from Inspector Barry dealing with the same subject.

It would appear to me that with one hundred pupils now in attendance at the school and the only exit, in case of sudden emergency, a single hallway, confusion might possibly arise.

As the Port Simpson Indian Council has agreed to provide the labor if the Department will supply the material, estimated by Mr. Gillett at $25, I would recommend provision of the doors asked for.

It will be noted that Mr. Gillett suggests that if favorable consideration could be given by the Department to this project, it might be cheaper to have the necessary material purchased in Vancouver and shipped to Port Simpson. I am not, however, prepared to agree with him as I consider that he is in a better position to purchase the doors, etc., in Prince Rupert, knowing as he does the size necessary and the other details with reference to painting and incidentals.

I would recommend that authority be given for the expenditure of a sum not exceeding $25 for the purchase of materials recommended by Mr. Gillett.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Sir:

With reference to the second paragraph of your letter, I would point out that when the Indian school was erected at Port Simpson a furnace was installed and, therefore, the two stoves formerly used in the old school became surplus to requirements and for that reason were disposed of. I would refer to your letter of August 21st, 1946, in which you state that 32 of the Port Simpson Indian Day School desks require replacement as this number is broken down and in the last stage of repair, the tops of many of these desks having been carved and defaced and in many cases the castings either wholly or partly fractured and broken. We have endeavoured to secure quotations on desks without results owing to steel strikes and slow delivery of certain hardwoods, and makers are unable to state when delivery can be made except for movable chair desks and progressive tables and chairs.

There would appear to have been the most deplorable lack of supervision by the teachers at this point of the pupils in the handling of school equipment to have permitted this wanton destruction to continue at a time when replacements have been most difficult to obtain and it would be appreciated if you would impress on the teachers that their fitness for the position will be assessed by their ensuring care of school property provided from public funds. If they are unable to ensure that this is done, they should undoubtedly be replaced or dismissed.

The Mission Indian Residential School are extremely anxious to secure desks and if they can be spared, I would request that you ship the ten best of these broken desks to the Reverend Principal, Indian Residential School, Mission, B.C. as they are in a position to make the necessary repairs in the school shop, having welding equipment.

Extract from Report of P.S. Tennant, M.D., dated February 13th, 1947. Original on file 315-6-3

FILE: 168-2-5 (Port Simpson)

In reference to your enquiry by wire re the water supply of the Crosby Home the following information is supplied. There are three separate water systems in Simpson all coming from separate sources viz streams from the mountains to the rear of the settlement.

The village has its own supply of water and also supplies the Hudson Bay store and white residences.

The hospital and doctors residence is supplied by a second stream. The pipe line is of wood stave pipe and is quite old.

The Crosby Home is supplied by a small stream with no one else tapping the source. Condition of the pipe line was not ascertained. The source is about ¼ of a mile from the home. The head of water is estimated at 150 feet or more. The dam is in a poor state of repair and requires to be replaced due partly to its condition, but also to increase storage in case of fire. When visited the reserve of water was nil due to zero weather here. There is no report of there having been a shortage of water in recent years however.
Prince Rupert, B.C.,

Res: Port Simpson Indian Day School.

Authority is requested to expend the sum not exceeding $25.00 for urgent repairs to the furnace at the Port Simpson Day School and the repair and installation of additional desks in the junior classroom.

The furnace is leaking gas fumes up into the building and will require cementing and asbestos packing to make it fume tight. In order to do this, it will be necessary to dismantle the casing and at the same time the furnace can be thoroughly cleaned.

The junior classroom has insufficient desks for the pupilage attending. It will be necessary to repair some of the old desks now stored in the school annexe and install these in the junior room.

Of the sum requested, $20.00 will cover the furnace repairs and $5.00 those of the desks. Immediate sanction of this work is recommended as the teachers are complaining of coal gas fumes.

Application is made to install bathroom plumbing and a hot water tank at the Fort Simpson Indian Day School. We have a chance of a lifetime to buy a basin, toilet and bath with fittings from the old hospital for $50.00. We can also secure sewer and water pipes and valves from the same source. A hot water tank can be bought for $20.00 f.o.b. Prince Rupert. There is a sewer line running from the Crosby Home right past the Day School and a hook-up with this line can be effected with ease. Mr. H. Brown, the caretaker at the hospital is a practical plumber and will do the work. There is provision for a bathroom in the upstairs quarters of the school.

Estimated cost:

Material ex hospital:
Toilet, bath and basin $50.00
Sink for kitchen $15.00
150' galvanized pipe-used, ½" $22.50
100 ft. sewer pipe @ 10¢, ¾ and 1" $10.00
Fittings, valves, shut offs, etc. $15.00 $112.50

Material ex Prince Rupert:
Standard hot water tank, with freight $24.00
Labour, 100 hours @ $1.00 an hour $100.00

Total estimated cost $236.50

This is a modern school and should have modern plumbing if we are going to hold good teachers. The work is strongly recommended. If approved an accountable advance for labour is requested.

F. Earl Anfield,
Superintendent,
Skeena River Agency.

Re: Port Simpson Indian Day School

With reference to Superintendent Anfield's letter of July 26th attached, while we have in the past been somewhat hesitant about the installation of plumbing facilities in Indian Day Schools the trend in school construction in British Columbia is definitely in this direction where such installations are feasible. In the case of the Fort Simpson school we have a modern building and the cost of installation of inside plumbing is reasonable. The installation of such facilities will be an added inducement to qualified teachers to accept positions in our schools and in the case of the Fort Simpson School I would recommend that the Department authorize Mr. Anfield to have the installation proceeded with at a cost of $236.50.

March 9, 1949

Extract from Report of Inspector R.F. Devey, on his inspection of the Fort Simpson Indian Day School on 9th February, 1949. Original on File 837-6.

GENERAL

The enrolment at this school has now reached the point where consideration should be given to the establishment of a third room. The small building at the back of the school presently used for manual training could be used for this purpose by the installation of an oil heater, blackboards and desks. This would be a temporary measure only until proper facilities could be provided. The living quarters readily lend themselves to adaptation to accommodate an extra teacher without overcrowding.

Considerable difficulty is experienced in heating this school. The present plant is a hot air system fired by coal. I believe that the Superintendent has had an experienced man examine the furnace but I am not familiar with his report. It would however seem that the blocking off of the openings between the rafters where the roof overhangs, the exterior walls would be helpful, particularly if the ceilings of the classrooms were insulated at the same time. It was also noted that the hot air conduits are not insulated in the usual manner by covering with asbestos. On each of my three visits to this school teachers have complained about the difficulty of heating all the rooms satisfactorily, and repairs amounting to twenty-five dollars were carried out on the furnace. It was apparently hoped that this work would provide the necessary adjustment to properly heat the school. This has not been accomplished. I suggest that a competent authority be sent to the school to determine the heating requirements.

Attached is a letter from Mr. Superintendent Anfield recommending the installation of an oil heater to heat the bedrooms in the upper portion of the teacherage at the Fort Simpson Indian Day School.

It will be recalled that Inspector Davey in his report on the above mentioned school mentioned the very unsatisfactory heating of the upstairs bedrooms of the teacherage.

It is considered that Mr. Anfield's recommendation is the most economical way of overcoming this difficulty and it is recommended that the expenditure of $150.00 as outlined in Mr. Anfield's letter be authorized.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Prince Rupert, B. C.
July 11th, 1949.

W. S. Arneil, Esq., Indian Commissioner for B. C., Box 70,
Vancouver, B. C.

Re: Port Simpson Indian Day School - Your file 12-11-3.

We are going to have difficulty heating the upstairs of this teacherage in any case. I was planning to utilize the fresh air vent that goes out through the ceiling of the upstairs and install through an aperture in the wall an oil burner. This would make the upstairs of this teacherage quite comfortable.

With regard to the store-room downstairs, this would make a useful bedroom provided we had accommodation for the large amount of school material presently stored therein. This could be taken care of by putting a partition in the annex and making a store-room therein.

I am satisfied that Miss Findlay would adjust to conditions at the Nursing Station if she were appointed senior teacher at the school. The other two teachers would be quite comfortable in the teacherage if an oil burner were installed upstairs.

This action is recommended. The oil heater will cost $125.00 installed and $25.00 should take care of labour for cutting the partition and installing same. Your instructions with regard to this matter will be appreciated so that the work may be completed during the summer, if possible.

F. Earl Amfeldt,
Indian Superintendent.

Application is made for the purchase of a new kitchen range for the teacherage at Port Simpson Indian Day School. The present range is burned through to the oven and is so badly warped as to be of no further use. It was installed when the school was built and as it was a very inexpensive type it has given fair service. The teachers have complained about it ever since I took over the Agency and if we are to get satisfied teachers, there will have to be a proper range put in.

Attached please find bid from the Hudson Bay Company, Port Simpson for a "Royal Crest" range at a price of $115.00 delivered and installed in the teacherage.

The purchase is recommended on this basis as it is almost impossible to get satisfactory labour at Port Simpson to install a range properly.

June 29th, 1949.

W. S. Arneil, Esq., Indian Commissioner for B. C., Box 70,
Vancouver.

Re: Port Simpson School.

Re your 12-11-3 of June 23rd, 1949, requesting information for the Department concerning the suitability of the parsonage at Port Simpson as a teacherage. The original "parsonage" is the old building opposite the Crosby Home. The Department would be well advised to keep out of this building. It is a huge ramshackle affair which will cost a fortune to heat and a large sum of money to put into any sort of shape. Under no circumstances could it be considered suitable for a teacherage.

I am, however, negotiating with the United Church for a price on this building with a view to taking it over as a possible residence for an Indian family of 14 people whose present quarters have been condemned by the Health authorities.

F. Earl Anfield.
Indian Superintendent.

Re: Port Simpson Indian Day School

In Supt. Anfield's letter of July 11th with regard to accommodation for the teachers at the above-mentioned school, a copy of which I forwarded you on July 20th, he suggested that two of the teachers could be accommodated in the teacherage and the third at the nursing station. It subsequently developed, however, that due to conditions beyond our control at the nursing station no accommodation would be available for one of the teachers and consequently it has been necessary to make quite extensive changes to the teacherage and it will also be necessary to provide additional furnishings.

The expenditures contemplated are as follows:

(1) Materials for changes to the teacherage $145.00
(2) Labour " " " " 150.00
(3) Purchase of kitchen & other equipment 73.29
(4) Purchase of furnishings 250.00
(5) Purchase & installation of oil heater 140.00

This item has already been approved reference Mr. Neary's letter of July 26th.

Although I regret having to confront the Department with these expenditures, in the absence of any accommodation for the teachers at the nursing station there would appear to be no alternative and I would ask you to please advise as soon as possible if they are approved.

W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Major D.M. McKay, Indian Commissioner, Vancouver, B.C.

With reference to your letter 215-4976 of the 18th inst., I have to say that I gave the Pacific Coast Militia Rangers permission to store their guns in the manual training building and they held an occasional evening instruction class. The key of the building was held by Miss Currie. Neither Miss Currie nor Miss Hill were the type to give the boys any instructions in carpenter work. We tried to secure the services of an Indian, but, any who were capable of teaching, were employed with other work.

J. Gillett
