June 29, 1943.

J. Gillett, Esq., Indian Agent, Prince Rupert, B.C.

Replying to your letter of the 23rd instant in which you state that the Pacific Coast Militia Rangers have your permission to store their guns in the manual training building at the Day School and use this room for occasional evening instruction classes, I would advise that I was under the impression that the P.C.M.R. kept their rifles in their homes ready for immediate use in case of an emergency.

In my opinion, the Community Hall would be preferable to the school for drills, etc., of this unit and the manual training room left available for the purpose for which it was intended. Every effort should be made to see that the children are given some vocational training as recommended by the Inspector of Schools.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ontario.

With further reference to my letter of the 18th instant regarding the Inspector's report covering the Port Simpson Indian Day School, I would advise that I took up with Mr. Indian Agent Gillett the question of use of the manual training room by a local organization and the lack of vocational instruction. In this connection, I enclose herewith his reply of the 23rd instant, and a copy of my letter of today's date addressed to him advising that the Indian Community Hall at Port Simpson would be the preferable place in which to hold instructional classes for the Pacific Coast Militia Rangers. This is a large building and should give them much more room for drills, etc. It is hoped that one of the new teachers to be appointed to this school may be able to give some instruction in vocational training.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

I beg to forward herewith a copy of a letter received from Mr. Indian Agent Gillett making application for authority to employ Peter Wells, an Indian carpenter of the Port Simpson Band, to teach the boys of the Port Simpson Indian Day School carpentry. It will be observed that instruction is to be given for two hours a week at the rate of $1.00 per hour.

This would appear to be a good opportunity to have some instruction in manual training given to the Port Simpson school boys and I have no hesitation in recommending that same be approved. It seems to me, however, that the period of only two hours a week is altogether too short, especially in view of the number of boys available for instruction, and that 2 two hour periods per week would be little enough. If the Department approves, it will be necessary to purchase some lumber, nails and other materials for instructional purposes for which an amount of approximately $40.00 will be required. The Department's decision in this matter by air mail would be appreciated.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dec. 24th, 1943.

Major D.M. Mackay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

RE: Manual Training at Port Simpson School.

Peter Wells, an Indian of Port Simpson, is willing to teach the boys carpentry at the Port Simpson Indian Day school for four months, January, February, March and April.

He is a good carpenter, having received his training at Coqualeetza, and is employed by the canneries during the summer for repair work to buildings and boats. He has built a number of houses for various Indians at Port Simpson. He would be willing to give instructions to the 24 boys for 2 separate hours in each week at $1.00 per hour. I recommend that he be engaged.

The material required is listed on Form 37 enclosed. We cannot secure the lumber in Prince Rupert. I would suggest, therefore, if the Department approves of the above being carried out, that all the material be purchased in Vancouver and shipped to Port Simpson by the U.S.S. "Catala" which leaves Vancouver every Friday.

If the Department has any designs for manual training work, I would appreciate having a sample.

J.G.

J. Gillett,
Indian Agent.

AIR MAIL

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, suggesting the appointment of Peter Wells to teach carpentry to the boys at the Port Simpson Indian Day School. In view of the comparatively small number of boys who will probably benefit from this training the Department feels that Wells should only be employed for two hours a week at the rate of $1.00 an hour. This arrangement should continue for the months of January, February and March and at the end of that time the work done should be reviewed and, if it is still your opinion that we should engage him for a longer period each week, we will be prepared to give favourable consideration to any recommendation you make.

Authority is also granted for the purchase of lumber, nails and other material for instructional purposes at an approximate cost of $40.00.

R.A. Hoey,

My dear Scott:

I enclose you a letter from Father A. Godfrey, who has charge of the Hagwilget Indians, within a mile or two of New Hazelton. This is a point that I have urged for some school, denominational, or otherwise, to be erected, as it is practically midway between all the banded Indians between Prince Rupert and Fort Fraser, and with the convenience of getting to school by both ends of the Railway, I know of no point which has such good arguments in its favor, as the above-mentioned.

Personally, I think the school would be of great benefit to the Indians there, who apparently have no school of any consequence. The Indians of the total district are industrious, and have made their living in the past, by packing, freight etc., through the different districts. Now, with the railway completed, it will mean that their vast livelihood will be in a great measure cut out, and I have always felt that it was your Department's duty to give them a better system of education.

However, you will note that Father Godfrey is asking for a reasonable salary for the teacher, and I certainly think this ought to be granted. It is a well-known fact that all laborers in the country get from $3 to $4 a day. I trust that you will give this your very best consideration and approval of some assistance along the lines I suggested. Father Godfrey, I know personally, has and is devoting a great deal of time and energy towards the different tribes of the district, and is well deserving of any assistance you can give him.

Truly yours,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

I very much regret that I feel compelled to write you regarding the non-receipt of my salary & bonds cheques for the quarter ended June 30th 1921.

I wish to respectfully inform you that I sent in my school report for that quarter on July 1st last to Mr. Edgar Hyde, Indian Agent, Hazelton, B.C.

I wish to point out that it has been the custom for me to use 2 forms when it has been found necessary; No. 1 form for the boys, & No. 2 form for the girls, adding up the totals of No. 1 form & carrying them forward to No. 2 form, filling up the "remark" column, making up the final totals, also giving a record of
School materials, Government property, etc., signing my name in the allotted spaces on No. 2 form then clipping the forms together by a patent clip securely, all this according to instructions furnished me by Mr. R.E. Loring, formerly Indian Agent at Hazelton B.C., witnessed by him now.

On Tuesday evening July 26th Mr. Hyde (Indian Agent) much to my surprise called on me bringing No. 1 School report form for me to sign (which I did at his request) although I felt sure that such an operation did not pertain before, I pointed out to him at the time that such an action would cause confusion at Ottawa, as he had already sent No. 2 form to a voucher to your Dept. which he stated was sent from here on July 10th that my cheques should have been here now (ie. July 26th) but now Aug. 13th.

The fact of the whole matter is this—Mr. Hyde must have detached the 2 report forms sending on No. 2 form with voucher, leaving No. 1 form laying around his office for "25 days" at least before finding out his mistake and unfortunately trying to lay the blame on me. This I do not accept as this is why I am writing to you to protest.
myself from all such accusations & incumbrances.

I have been in the service of your Dept. for nearly 8 years & many reports have been made out by me during that time & not one error has ever been made in any of them.

Furthermore, when Mr. Hyde assumed office here as Indian Agent, one of my first things was to render him all the assistance I could in giving him information regarding the Indians located in Hagwilget Reserve, quite recently furnishing him with all the names of the old Indians & when compiling his Census returns, therefore I think respect is due tome, the value of information given by those who have been in the service of your Dept. for so many years should be appreciated, recognised by him. It would save him a vast amount of time & trouble, especially when it comes to fixing school reports etc.

Having been brought up business myself, I expect things done in a business-like manner.

The forwarding of my salary & bonus cheques for quarter ended June 30th, by you as soon as possible would be appreciated. I trust that in future they may be received.
much earlier than what has pertained heretofore. It would indeed be a welcome change. We have justifiable reasons for mentioning this fact.

During the period herein mentioned the average attendance of pupils at school were 17.46; the number of days school was open, 200; the number of biscuits per box $2.40 (20 doz); the maximum price per box $4.00 working out at the rate of about 1/4 biscuits or 2 cents per child, per school day.

Regarding his Inspection of the ROCHER DEBOULE
INDIAN DAY SCHOOL on October 21, 1931.

Original on File 151-3-6.

Vocational:

The girls make dresses and underclothes, etc., in school. They learn to knit and to do needlework. This work is well done. The school won a $10 prize at the Kamloops Fair. Mrs. Browning has been in charge of this work. The Department pays her a yearly salary of $140.00. I am asked by Mrs. Browning if it would be possible for her to have an increase in salary. I told her that I could not recommend that, as there was not much money available for the schools.// I am not certain that I can recommend the retention of the services of Mrs. Browning in the school. These teachers have been in the school for very many years. I do not think that a person suffering from the nervous twitchings and jerkings so pronounced as in the case of Mrs. Browning is a fit person to be in a school with young children. Mr. Browning's control of the children is very weak. He seems to have little idea of control of children and to rely on going around amongst them with a ruler or stick to urge them on to greater effort. In place of asking the Department to terminate the engagement of these teachers at the end of the school year, I most strongly urge that the Department will let them know that I am not satisfied with either the work of the children or their methods of control. I hope that the Department will instruct the Indian Agent to visit the school often during the remainder of the school year and to report if there has been much improvement as a result of my inspection.

Meeting of Tsitak Indians by Inspector G. H. Barry,
ra - Sydney Browning, late teacher, Rochar Deboule
Indian Day School.

Whilst I was away at the Babine Lake Reserves, School
Inspector G. H. Barry visited this Agency and was asked to
attend a meeting of the Tsitak (Hagwilget) Indians concerning
Mr. Sydney Browning, late teacher of the Rochar Deboule Indian
Day School. This meeting was held on September 14th and the
following is a report taken from notes by Mr. Mallinson, clerk
of this Agency.

Three of the leading Tsitak Indians spoke asking that
Mr. Browning be re-appointed as teacher of the Rochar Deboule
School, giving as their reasons the good work Mr. Browning had
done for their children; for his help to the destitute; for his
counsel and advice to all; for his church work and for his
social work generally. They stated he had been teacher of the
school for over twenty years and that he had done very good work.
They also stated they were very glad to meet Inspector Barry.

Inspector Barry, in his reply, stated that he was glad
to meet the Indians of Tsitak and had carefully noted what had
been said with regard to Mr. Browning and the good work he had
done both at the school and in the village. He informed the
meeting that Mr. Browning had resigned as teacher of the Rochar
Deboule Indian Day School and that the Indian Department had
accepted his resignation. He mentioned that the Indian
Department, like all other departments of the Dominion Government,
had a rule that all members must retire from duty on reaching the
age of 65 and that Mr. Browning had already reached that age.
Consequently his term of office was at an end and that his place
must be filled by some other person. He stated that the Roman
Catholic Church had put forward the name of the new teacher, Mrs.
Macdonald, and that the Indian Department had approved of this
choice and appointed Mrs. Macdonald as teacher of the Rochar
Deboule Indian Day School. He mentioned that he had given
about four hours to Mrs. Macdonald, instructing her in the methods
of teaching as set forth by the Department of Indian Affairs, and
he was sure this lady would do her best to make the school studies
interesting and do everything possible for her pupils. He hoped
the Indians of Tsitak would help Mrs. Macdonald in every way and
give her a chance to make good. He also stated that the new
teacher had only recently come to the reserve and that she could
not possibly do, at once, all that Mr. Browning did after twenty
years' experience with the Indians of the Tsitak Reserve. He
asked the Indians to give Mrs. her time - probably several months -
and their constant help and he was sure that Mrs. Macdonald would
be very much liked and loved by all on the Tsitak Reserve. He
stated that Mrs. Macdonald, besides being an experienced teacher,
was a trained nurse and would be of great help to all in time of
sickness. Inspector Barry thanked the Indians for their kind
attention.

I am informed Inspector Barry called upon Mr. Browning
directly he reached Hazelton at the latter's request.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Report: Reports and timetable satisfactory. Progress records should be brought up to date. Control good. An attempt has been made to group the children according to their mastery of past work. Pupils assist in classroom duties. Junior Red Cross. Good use is made of the library. Hot lunch programme during winter months.

Work is planned and prepared, but could be better organized on a more systematic basis. Time for study has been stressed throughout the fundamental skills and the attainment of the appreciation and content subjects. Teaching is thorough but tends to underestimate the capacity for growth of the pupils. More attention should be paid to silent reading in the upper grades. The emphasis on rote spelling of unfamiliar words is not conducive to reading development. Content detail rather than general principles have been stressed in social studies. Individual attention has been given to the pupils. The Spirit of the Programme of Studies should be followed more closely than the organization of work on a purely text-book basis.

It is hard to estimate the progress of the pupils, as it is evident that the work of previous grades was not completed satisfactorily. The result has been an attempt to complete all the work of previous grades in each subject. Although the principle of learning no gaps in the mastery of necessary skills is good teaching practice care must be taken to ascertain exactly what those gaps are and to teach accordingly. In the Primary grades reading progress is good, although there is a tendency to word-calling which should be checked. The Grade IV group is below standard in reading comprehension. Grade V is reading well. Spelling progress is good and writing fair. There is a good grasp of arithmetic fundamentals. Grade VIII has done little work in mathematics at its own grade level. Pupils show a willingness to learn, but are not advancing rapidly enough to retain interest. It is not desirable to "prove" in writing every answer in arithmetic once the pupils know how to make a quick check.

Mrs. Chapman has conscientiously tried to teach each pupil at the level of mastery reached. Greater familiarity with modern teaching and testing techniques, and with the Programme of Studies would have saved a lot of time and brought quicker results.

Signed. F.P. Levirs

January 15, 1948

Dear Colonel Neary,

Thank you for your recent letter dealing with the subject of the Indian school children at Haqwilget Reserve.

Frankly, I was hoping that some other solution than that of sending them to a non-denominational school would be found by your department. It might not be appropriate for me to go into the most serious reason for disliking such a solution, namely, the lack of Catholic environment, but it seems to me that, if an effort in this direction has not already been made, you might instruct your Agent at Hazelton to have the children sent for the rest of this year to Lejac School. If there were some way of taking care of them in Moricetown, they could be sent there as an alternative, to the day school. But I realize that it would be difficult at present to carry out such a plan.

Having thus expressed my view, and knowing that the situation is a difficult one, I shall say no more on this subject.

However, I should like to take advantage of this opportunity to remark that the whole educational setup as it affects Catholic Indian children is sadly deficient. To seek to assess and apportion blame is a waste of time.

The problem is constantly on my mind and I would like to tell you what I think would help. If we could place teaching Sisters, say a minimum of two, on each reserve, along with a qualified nursing Sister, we would in five years bring about astonishing changes in education, family life and hygiene.

I have been in touch with Irish nuns, all of whom are either trained...
teachers or graduate nurses. Their whole work at present is in Northern Africa. When I invited them to come to Canada, the reply was that the acceptance of such an invitation would require a change in their Constitutions. Such a change would have to be made at a General Chapter which meets in May of this year. The Mother General and her Council would make no promises but expressed their willingness to consider the change.

Now, Colonel Neary, if they accept my invitation, I should need the cooperation of your Department. I realize that unauthorized teachers cannot be placed on the Reserves. You will agree however that the advent of Sisters, say to Babine, where I should like them to be established, would be a boon to the Department. Moricetown, and Stony Creek (there are other places, too) could be taken care of in the same way in the course of time.

The Sisters have not accepted yet and there will be no answer for four months, but could you tell me if there would be any likelihood of the Department approving them, if two names of Sisters were presented as teachers next fall or in 1949? Let me add, that it is not my wish that any teachers now occupying posts, e.g., at Babine, be pushed out to make room for the Sisters. Mr. and Mrs. Berwick at Babine would like to leave there but would like to be sure that there are others to take their place. Naturally, I have not spoken to them of my plan, nor shall I, until I know the views of the Department and know for certain that the Sisters are coming.

If you say to me that I should have had the Department's opinion before approaching the Sisters, I shall agree entirely. Yet, I hope I am not amiss in presuming that the Department is favourable to any change that will make the Indians of this territory less a problem than they are and are likely to be for a long time.

Kind personal regards.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Reference 1-11-3 (151) of February 3.

We have recently received a letter from Bishop Jordan with regard to the proposals advanced for bringing the children from Moricetown into Hazelton to the proposed consolidated school. In his letter he states as follows:

"Frankly, I was hoping that some other solution than that of sending them to a non-denominational school would be found by your Department. It might not be appropriate for me to go into the most serious reason for disliking such a solution, namely, the lack of Catholic environment, but it seems to me that, if an effort in this direction has not already been made, you might instruct your Agent at Hazelton to have the children sent for the rest of this year to Lejac School. If there were some way of taking care of them in Moricetown, they could be sent there as an alternative, to the day school. But I realize that it would be difficult at present to carry out such a plan".

Size of School:

Therefore, it would seem that a decision will now have to be reached as to whether a 2 or 4 room school would be required at Hazelton. We have plans on hand for both of these types of schools but do not have a 3 room school plan available. It will take some months to make such a plan and before proceeding with this step, I would appreciate hearing from you as to the exact size of school which will be required.
It is noted that Mr. Arthur Mowatt of the Hazelton Band has asked $400.00 an acre for a two acre proposed site. In view of the fact that this land will be used for a school site and for Indian Education, it is felt that this price is decidedly high.

Elsewhere Indians have allowed the Branch a reduced rate when they realized that the property was going to become a school site to provide better education for all the Indians on the Reserve. The Department feels that when we are providing everything for the education of these Indians, the least that can be expected of them is to provide property for a school site at a reduced rate. As you are only too well aware white property owners have done this when Provincial Schools are being built. Would you please, therefore, have Mr. Indian Agent Boys approach Mr. Mowatt with regard to the obtaining of a reduced rate for this land.

I would also refer you to Inspector Davey's report of January 30, 1947 and attached map as prepared by Inspector Coleman. It would be appreciated if we could be advised as to whether there is access from the road, west of the Arthur Mowatt site into the proposed school. It is felt that the children from the bottom of the bench should be provided with access to the new school without having to go in a round about way.

Reference your 1-11-3 (151) of June 29

I was pleased to note the action taken previously by Inspector Davey and yourself with regard to this school.

A letter has been sent to Bishop Jordan informing him of the prospects of re-opening this school and the possibility of building a new school in 1950-51. It has been pointed out to him that the success of this venture depends entirely on the co-operation of the Indian parents and children. He has therefore been requested to secure the assistance of his Missionary in persuading the Indian parents to have their children attend regularly.

Bernard E. Neary,

Kispiox Indian Day School

Ref.: your C-11-2(151) of October 13

We have contacted our Chief Treasury Officer with reference to salary cheques for the teachers at the above schools in your superintendency.

Mr. George Thiessen, teacher at the Rocher Deboule Indian Day School, was sent his first salary cheque on October 11, 1949. We were advised by you in a letter dated September 21, 1949, that he had commenced teaching duties on September 15. It is presumed that he has now received his first salary cheque.

A cheque was mailed to Mr. H. Schroeder, teacher at the Kitwanebool Indian Day School, on October 4, 1949. On October 7, 1949, we received a letter from Mr. Schroeder advising us that he had received his Second Class Certificate. We, therefore, reclassified him as a Grade II teacher, and he will be paid at this new rate effective September 1, 1949. His salary cheques will be adjusted accordingly. Salary letters have been sent to Mr. Schroeder quoting both old and new rates.

On October 8, 1949, we received the necessary T.D.I forms for Mrs. J.M. Hogarth, teacher at the Kispiox Indian Day School. In answer to our Army Signal we were advised of the date Mrs. Hogarth commenced duties and immediately sent a memorandum to Treasury appointing her effective September 1, 1949. Her cheque will be mailed to her during the course of the next week.
Would you please convey this information to each of the three teachers and assure them that we wish to hear from them again if there is any further delay.

Bernard J. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Sir,

I wish to respectfully inform you that I sent in my school report for December quarter (1920) to Mr. R.E. Loring, Indian Agent, Hazelton B.C., on December 20th, 1920, this date being part of the usual procedure also according to receipt and ordinary procedure, with the understanding that all salary cheques in future will be sent direct to all teachers.

It is now Jan. 31st, 1921, two weeks have turned up, why this delay? Need my money, at least within 30 days after sending in reports. According to rules and regulations of your dept., it states that all salaries would be paid immediately on receipt by your Dept. of school reports, surely it does not take 30 days to perform this task, especially when I know that it is possible to receive an answer from Ottawa within 12 days.

I have been over years in the service of your dept. as school teacher & having kept a record etc.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6408, file 838-3, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
I find it has taken on an average five weeks from the time school reports are sent in, up to the time of receiving salary cheques; the whole thing could be done within 30 days, even after allowing 4 or 5 days for the perusal of the various school reports by the officials at your depot. The school is so far removed from civilization that what reports could be sent in, are sent in good time; certainly no teacher would delay his or her report.

I would respectfully call your attention also that I am perfectly justified within my right as an inhabitant of Canada for over 20 years, in demanding more substantial in payment of my salary. Faithfully perform my tasks as school teacher to meet my salary paid with the least possible delay and records furthermore I know for a fact, school reports are "held up" at this end & bureaucratic methods are adopted by your Indian Agent at Hazelton B.C. & I think it is high time such "tortuous" procedures should cease.

Then again I would remark that the yearly statistics covering the Babine Agency have been...
compiled and written by me during the past weeks, your Indian Agent being incompetent of performing that task.

Promptitude in the payment of my salary in the future would be greatly appreciated. I am entitled to the full value and interest of my hard earned money.

Yours respectfully,

Sydney Brebner

Duncan C. Scott Esq.,
Deputy Chief of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.
Addendum.

Tuesday, Oct 1st 1921.

As the train from the east was due here today, I was in hopes that "salary cheques" would arrive, but I was again doomed to disappointment. It seems strange that such delays should be allowed to exist. It is not business. I have my obligations to meet, not receiving my salary cheques in good time puts me (and other teachers) to great inconvenience & often means extra expense. This should not pertain in a modern country. Do you think so?

Yours truly,

Sydney Browning.
Ottawa, February 9, 1921.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 31st ultimo regarding the non-receipt of your salary cheque for the quarter ending December 31st, last.

In reply I beg to say that your quarterly return reached the Department on the 26th of January and a cheque for $225.00, being the amount of salary due you, was mailed on the 28th of that month. This cheque was sent c/o Dr. H. C. Wrinch, Acting Indian Agent, Hazelton, B.C.

It is noted that your return for the December quarter is certified to by Dr. Wrinch on January 17th. There has evidently been delay, owing to the recent change whereby R.E. Loring has been retired from the service, in mailing your return from Hazelton to the Department. I may say that all returns are checked promptly in the Department and cheques for the amount of salary due sent without delay. It is regretted that you have been inconvenienced by the non-receipt of your salary cheque, but the delay in this case was not through any fault of the Department here.

Your bonus cheque for the December quarter was mailed on the 4th instant, also addressed c/o Dr. Wrinch. It is hoped that you have received both your salary and bonus cheques before this date.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sydney Browning, Esq.,
Teacher,
Rocher Deboule Indian Day School,
P. O. Box 28,
New Hazelton, B.C.

Dear Sir,

I wish to respectfully call your attention to a letter I received from the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa as far back as January 12, 1920 wherein it states that my salary would be increased from $750.00 to $900.00 per annum as from April 1st, 1919; that being so, each year from the date mentioned would commence on the last April of one year and end on March 31st of the following year running consecutively, and up to a certain date I received payment of salary, viz:

| Month       | Year   | Amount |
|-------------|--------|--------|
| June        | 1923   | $225.00|
| Sept.       | 1923   | $90.00 |
| Dec.        | 1923   | $270.00|
| March       | 1924   | $270.00|

Total $855.00

Yearly salary...$900.00
Amount received...$55.00

Arrears due to March 31st 1924 $45.00 (To make each year complete)

Although I am fully aware that a change in the method of payment of teachers' salaries (10 month basis) was brought into operation in September last, that does not however alter the fact that an increase in salary became effective as from April 1st, 1919; that being so, it is necessary and reasonable that I should receive the arrears of salary which really became due for the June quarter 1923.

I wish to point out also that all teachers have not received their appointments in the month of September, I would be glad therefore if you could get this matter rectified, as I feel that I am fully entitled to the $45.00 arrears of salary herein mentioned.

Yours respectfully
Signed.... Sydney Browning
Teacher.

P.S. Mr. R.H. Cairns (Inspector of Indian Schools) also reckons the attendance of pupils from June 30th of one year to March 31st of the following year. (June Qtr. 1920 to March 31st 1924)
Sir,

I enclose herewith for your perusal, copy of a letter, which is self-explanatory, received from Mr. Sydney Browning, the Teacher at the Rocher Deboule Indian Day School.

All teachers in this Agency received Departmental letter No.1-1-3 dated September 17th, 1923. I have explained to Mr. Browning on several occasions that the school year ends on June 30th of each year, and at the end of this quarter he will receive $270.00, which will make up the $900.00 for the ten months - Sept. to June.

Your obedient Servant,

Indian Agent

The Secretary,

Ottawa, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, November 11th, 1925.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector Cairns, in a report on his inspection of the Roche Deboule Indian Day School dated October last, recommends that Mrs. Browning, the assistant teacher, be granted an increase of $20 in her salary. At the present time she is in receipt of $120 per annum for her services in the teaching of sewing, knitting, etc., and the preparation of the noonday meal for the children. She is also in receipt of salary at the rate of $60 per annum for her services as janitress. In view of the Inspector's recommendation, we have decided to grant Mrs. Browning an increase of $20 in her salary as assistant teacher. This will make her salary from the 1st of October, last, at the rate of $14 per month for the ten teaching months in the year.

It will not, in future, be necessary for you to prepare a separate voucher for Mrs. Browning's salary as assistant teacher. This voucher will be prepared in the Department and a cheque will be sent her at the same time as salary is being paid to Mr. Browning, the teacher. You should, however, prepare and forward a voucher for the amount due her at the end of each quarter for her services as janitress.

Please inform Mrs. Browning of the increase at the rate of $20 per annum allowed her in her salary as assistant teacher.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Ottawa, July 30, 1935.

Sir:

I have to inform you that Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Browning have retired as from June 30th last, as teachers at the Recher Debeule Indian Day School.

His Lordship Bishop Bunoa has recommended and nominated the services of Mrs. James Macdonald, Smithers, B. C., as teacher of this school for the coming academic year. The Department is approving of her appointment, with salary at the rate of $90 per teaching month.

It is not intended to fill the position of assistant teacher, as it is considered that the work of the school can be satisfactorily carried on under one teacher.

Mr. Agent Mortimer, who forwarded the nomination of Mrs. Macdonald, is being informed of the approval granted for her appointment and the salary allowed. I would request that you advise Mr. Inspector Barry of this appointment.

During the course of my visits to the Roche Dehoule and Kispiox Indian Day schools I found that the seating accommodation was not satisfactory, especially for the larger boys and girls, as the desks are too near the floor. May I suggest to the Department that I be allowed to purchase from R. S. Sargent, Limited of Hazelton, 26 pieces of 2" x 4" x 16' and 400 - 1/2" screws. It is my intention to place the lumber under the legs of the desks which will give sufficient room to the larger children and will be more satisfactory. The approximate cost will be:

I would further draw the attention of the Department to the Kispiox School, the roof of which is leaking badly. This school has roofing paper, a large portion of which has been torn off, allowing the snow to melt through and fall into the school. Ottawa, March 14, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 7th instant, regarding the alterations required in the desks at the Rocher Deboule and Kispiox Indian Day Schools in order to provide proper seating accommodation for the larger boys and girls.

In reply I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase of 26 pieces of scantling and the quantity of screws required, as mentioned in your letter, and have this lumber placed under the legs of the desks in order to make them more satisfactory. It is noted you estimate the total cost of the lumber and screws to be approximately $10.75.

Regarding the condition of the roof of the Kispiox Indian Day School, I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase of two rolls of two-ply roofing paper, and have the repairs carried out.

After the work in connection with the desks and roof has been completed, please forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of the material and for the labour in having the work carried out. If possible, the accounts should show the expenditure for each of these schools separately.

Form No. 101
Sir,

re - Lunch at the Kicher Deboule Indian Day School.

I respectfully beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of October 19th with reference to Pilot bread for the Kicher Deboule Indian Day School at Tsitsik.

To-day I visited this school and interviewed Mr. Browning, the Teacher, regarding the lunch, and of what it was composed, which is daily given to the children. Soup made from bones with peas, beans and potatoes added is given three times a week and cocoa is given the other two days. At each meal every child is given one Pilot bread biscuit. The average attendance at this school is fourteen (14) children and four boxes of Pilot bread lasts four months, the cost of same being $4.25 per box. As the new scale allowed for groceries for this school is cut from $7.50 to $3.50 per month the average daily cost per child, including Pilot bread, is approximately 2½¢.

I may state that Tsitsik is one of my poorest reserves and I am of the opinion that one hot meal each day is a blessing to the children.

May I respectfully suggest that this be continued.

GCM/SM.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Ottawa, July 5th, 1933.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of your Voucher 103 for $45.00, covering the rent of the Recher Deboule Indian Day School for the June quarter. This account is being paid.

As you are aware, our appropriation has been considerably reduced and the Department would appreciate your endeavouring to secure this building at a lower rate. We have been allowing $15.00 a month for several years past and the Department considers that the owner should be disposed to accept a lower rental. Please give this matter your immediate attention and advise the Department.

Your vouchers numbered 118 and 119, covering the cost of midday meal supplies, have also been received and these accounts are being paid. I would point out, however, that, owing to the reduction in our appropriation, very careful consideration will have to be given to what amount can be allowed for midday meal purposes during the coming academic year.

Midday meals should not be served at any of the schools in your agency during the month of September but, when the teachers return after the summer holidays, you should discuss the matter very carefully with them and advise the Department regarding the minimum amount required at each school where a midday meal has been served in the past.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Sir,

re - Mid-day meals at Roche Deboise Indian Day School, Tsitsik Reserve.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of July 6th regarding the mid-day meals for the school children of Tsitsik Reserve. I concur with the Department's suggestion that mid-day meals need only be supplied to the children of this school from November 1st to April 30th.

Although objection has been taken to this curtailment of the mid-day meal by the teacher, Mr. Browning, which may result in the Indians petitioning this office when the school opens, I am of opinion, with the plentiful supply of fresh fish and vegetables, that the children will not suffer on account of the reduced period.

May I suggest that $5.00 per month be allowed for these mid-day meals at this school, which would include Pilot bread.

It is with feelings of keen regret that the Dept. of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, should desire to stop supplying the mid-day meals for Indian school children at this point for the months of September, October etc., as mentioned in your note of recent date.

As you are fully aware (more particularly) of the circumstances and conditions prevailing among the Indians living in this Indian Reserve and their precarious mode of living (not at all times providing meals at the proper meal hours) and my own personal knowledge and experience with these Indians as teacher here for nearly 20 years should be sufficient evidence and reason as to the necessity of continuing the mid-day meals for the IC school months of the year, and as it was found (owing to the poverty of the Indians of this Reserve) by the dept. of Indian Affairs, Ottawa to grant $7.50 per month for mid-day meals from (which was cut down to $3.30 recently) from Sept. 1916, and at a time when adult Indians could find much work to do in and around this district, it seems more necessary now when there is no work not even for white to do. You ask me what the minimum cost would be for providing these meals. I would respectfully point out that the amount hitherto granted, viz.- $3.30 for soup ingredients etc., plus $3.80 for Pilot Bread equals $7.10 per school month, or $71.00 for 1 school year of 10 months, a very insignificant amount when compared with that which pertains at any Indian Residential School, and I would state that
Mrs Browning has often used some of her own cooking ingredients in making soups for these poor little Indian children; so then the amount is mighty small.

The mid-day meal although very small, is still of nourishment to the school children and has been appreciated, helping them considerably with their studies, as without proper nourishment and sustenance no child can possibly learn well, a very important fact is it not? I think that if the facts were fully explained and made thoroughly clear by you to the Dept. of Indian Affairs, Ottawa they would not begrudge the small amount expended each School year for that purpose.

Thanking you for any assistance you can render in this important matter,

I am,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Sydney Browning

Teacher.

Sir,-

In reporting on his visit to the Roche Deboule Indian Day School on September 15th, last, Inspector Barry states that the house in which the school is held is very unsatisfactory. He further states that Mr. Mallinson, who accompanied him, pointed out one or more other Indian houses where it might be possible to locate the school.

As you are aware, the Department allows $10.00 a month for the building used for school purposes on the Roche Deboule Reserve. In view of Inspector Barry's report, it is considered advisable for you to endeavour to make arrangements for a more suitable house. The rent, of course, will be the same as at present allowed.

Sir,

re - Rocher Deboule Indian Day School Building.

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of October 22nd regarding the above mentioned matter.

The present school building is very unsatisfactory. I personally inspected several houses which I thought might be suitable buildings for school purposes but found none large enough to hold the seventeen desks, heater and teacher's equipment.

I am endeavouring to have the present school building sufficiently repaired to withstand the incoming winter. However, when spring comes I will again take up this matter with the Department.

I may say that the present teacher is living in the Priest's house, there being no other suitable for occupancy.

Your obedient servant,

G. C. Mortimer,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

Re assembling School Desks, Tsitsik Reserve.

I am in receipt of your letter dated May 10th 1939 with returned vouchers regarding the excessive cost of assembling new desks and dismantling old desks and rebuilding same.

In reply may I state that the dismantling of the old desks and rebuilding them was a very arduous job, the work of assembling of the new desks did not nearly so long to do.

I personally visited the school on two occasions to hasten the work, and could plainly see that it would be a tedious job, especially with the old broken desks.

Trusting this explanation will be satisfactory.

Your obedient Servant

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 16th instant with reference to the amount paid for rental of the school and teacher's residence at Roche Deboule.

Your letter is the first intimation that we have received that these buildings were not owned by the Indian Joe Nachlach.

We have no objection to issuing two cheques in future provided you forward the necessary vouchers but owing to present conditions it is not possible to increase the monthly rent of $10.00.

Dear Sir,

re- Rent of Rocher Deboule Day School Building and Teacher's Residence.

I enclose a letter from Rev. J.B. Samuel, O.M.I., New Hazelton, B.C., asking that a reasonable rent be allowed for the residence of the teacher of the Rocher Deboule Indian Day School, Tsitak Reserve.

On July 5th, 1933, under File 151-3-5, the Department suggested that the school building be secured at a lower rate than $15.00 per month, to which Mr. Indian Agent Mortimer replied on August 21st., 1933, File L-2-240, stating that $10.00 per month would be acceptable to the Indian owner.

Apparently the former rent was for the school building and the teacher's residence, $10.00 being paid for the former and $5.00 for the latter, per month. Under the new arrangement the Indian owner of the school building has given $2.50 per month to the Resident Priest of Tsitak as rent of the teacher's residence.

The teacher's residence, owned by the Roman Catholic Church, is well built and a good deal of money has been spent in making it habitable and comfortable. Might I suggest that a rent of at least $6.00 per month be allowed for this building.

The amount of $7.50 per month is ample for the school building.

Will you kindly advise what attitude the Department might take in this matter?

Yours faithfully,

S. Mallinson,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

I would like to call the attention of the Department on the following facts:

The teacher of the Indian School at Hagwilget resided for two years in the Mission's house. Since three years the Mission has given to the Teacher's disposition a well built frame house, comfort of 4 large rooms, two downstairs and two upstairs.

By an anomaly I do not understand, the rent for that house was merged with the rent for the school building. Every three months the cheque was addressed to Joe Naclash or Naclash who kept $22.50 and gave to the Mission $7.50.

May the Department consider the situation and allow us a fair deal. The teacher's residence is a far better building than the school building and the rent for the latter is $7.50 and for the former $22.50.

You will understand immediately the wrong of the situation. May I ask the Department through your kind service, to allow us a reasonable rent, the same at least they for the school building of far inferior cost and importance, and to directly address to "the Catholic Mission of New Hazelton" the check for the rent of the teacher's residence, distinct definitively from the amount coming to the owner of the school.

Hoping for a satisfactory settlement, I am

Yours very truly

(Signed) Rev. J.B. Samuel OMI

Hazelton, B.C.,
August 27th, 1946.

D. M. MacKay, Esq., Indian Commissioner for B.C., Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

A tentative application has been received from Miss Grace Wishart of Prince Rupert, to teach at Hagwilget school during the coming year. This application, made through the Rev. J. Donze, is submitted with the proviso that a furnished Teacherage be made available. At present we rent a building from the R.C. Church at $5.00 per month, but apart from a heater recently acquired from the former incumbent, Mrs. Macdonald, the quarters are completely unfurnished.

The following is a list of requirements:

- Kitchen Stove
- Bed and mattress
- Table
- Chairs
- Linoleum mats 9 x 12
- Studio Lounge
- Curtains
- Kitchen utensils and crockery.

Will you kindly advise at your earliest convenience if the Department would consider providing these furnishings, and if so, will you kindly place an order for same in Vancouver, since they are not obtainable locally.

Miss Wishart, who I believe has taught Indians before, also wishes to know if a subsistence allowance could be made until such time as the Teacherage is furnished.

JB/bc

J. J. Boys,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Inspector's Report -
Roche Debeule Indian Day School

Dear Bishop Jordan:

District School Inspector Davey visited the above Indian Day School on October 31. His Inspector's report on the teacher is quite unsatisfactory. On the teacher grading scale D (poor) is given for Personality, Management, Teaching Skill and Pupils' Progress. Under general comments Inspector Davey writes as follows:

"The work of this teacher is most unsatisfactory. There is little evidence of any progress since my last visit, and practically none of the recommendations made on that occasion have been implemented. Attendance at the school is most irregular and although the teacher is inclined to blame this on the indifference of the parents, it is felt that the chief reason lies in the methods and the personality of the teacher. It is apparently impossible to impress this teacher with the need to follow even the elementary principles. There is a complete lack of organization. No attempt is made to follow a time-table. The teacher was not even sure of the grades in which the pupils had been classified.

"The school building is a very old structure quite beyond repair, and in view of the proximity of the village to Hazelton, it is felt that when the new school at Hazelton is erected it would be advisable to transport

Most Reverend A. Jordan, O.M.I., D.D.,
Vicar Apostolic of Prince Rupert,
Box 776, Prince Rupert, B.C.
the few pupils to a combined school. This would be a distance of only some three miles. The cost of such a scheme would be far cheaper and the results much better than the operation of two separate schools."

You will recall that I wrote to you on July 15, 1947, concerning a similar proposal made last year. I would appreciate hearing from you with regard to future plans for the Rochele Deboule Indian Day School. Our records indicate that only nine children are now in attendance, with an average daily attendance of five.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

SPECIAL REPORT ON TSARTLIP DAY SCHOOL, SOWICHAN AGE

I have the honor to report that I visited this school on the morning of September 27th. I found the school closed. I saw the priest, Rev. Father Rendall, who lives close to the school house. He said the school was "dead". I found him very unreasonable in his remarks. I then went to see the teacher who lives about a quarter of a mile from the school. She said she only had school three weeks in the December quarter, that she went again and again, and as the pupils did not come she stopped going. I asked if she would still teach if the children came and she said she would.

I afterwards saw a number of the Indians. They declared the children went to the school house, and not finding the teacher they returned home. After doing this several times they decided it was no use going.

These Indians were formerly nearly all good Catholics, but a number joined a new sect "Shakers", a dancing religion! The priest properly reproved his people for this, and a hard feeling exists between priest and Indians at the present time. Some think they are getting even with him by not sending their children to school.

I consider the teacher has shown lack of interest in the school the past few months. There are only nine children of school age on the reserve at present and they live quite a distance from the school house. Unless the Indians and the teacher take an interest in the school it would be better to close it. Some of the Indians said they did not wish the school closed.

The priest said it was not his work, and that he would not go and ask the people to send their children to the school.

I have the honor to remain

Your obedient servant

Dear Sir,

Mr. Agent W. R. Robertson wrote to me on the 15th inst., quoting an extract from your letter to him, Feb. 24th last respecting non-attendance at the Ventilpa Day School. In that extract I note the statement that "this non-attendance would appear to be due to lack of interest both on the part of the missionary and the teacher."

That statement compels me to say, in self-defence, that for the securing of proper attendance at Indian schools more than the interest of the missionary and teacher is required, and that we, who it is evident that other proper agencies have been utilized to the full, should so serious an implication be made as to the missionary and teacher. What evidence may I add, has the department that full interest has been shown, and full effort made by others charged with office with working for the success of our Indian educational policy? How many official visits have been made to the school within the year? What official efforts have been made to secure full attendance? For my part I have done and am doing all I possibly can to that end. The teacher is doing more than one can reasonably be expected to do for a salary of $25.00 a month. In these days
and in our country that is a mere pittance. To ensure enthusiastic effort on the part of the teacher a salary fairly commensurate with the work should be paid. And the efforts of even a well paid teacher are all systems short, must be regularly and efficiently supplemented by the local officials and more particularly by the inspectors of Indian schools. I may add that my experience long ago led me to the conclusion that the legal provision for compulsory education should be enforced. Compulsory education is required to secure the education of all white children whose parents have been for generations subjected to an environment making in favor of their general understanding of the benefit, may the necessity of education, surely create means cannot be counted on to secure the extension of education to the children of a people who but a short time ago emerged from barbarism.

I can assure the department that as a missionary I can be counted upon to do all in my power to help in the work of education; but I must have effective help.

Clear evidence of governmental determination to have the Indian children educated is the surest way to ensure attendance at school of these children. Closing a school is not a punishment to delinquent parents, that simply cuts off the possibility of educating for the children.

Hoping that you will favorably consider these remarks and consequently exempt both myself and the teacher from blame we decidedly do not deserve.

Yours Truly,

The Rev. Father M. M. Rondan.
I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letters of the 9th November and 13th instant, with further reference to Indians of the West Saanich Indian Reserve attending the public school in that vicinity.

Since then I have canvassed the situation to see just what can be done for the children of this reserve to afford them educational facilities nearer home than the residential schools at Rupert Island or at Sardis. There are twenty-two children of school age on the West Saanich Reserve and fourteen under school age. These figures are exclusive of five at Rupert Island School and one at Coqualeetza. The parents say they would all like to have the old Day School re-opened and would have their children attend regularly if this were done, but they want a good teacher.

The old school building has been examined and it is found to be in need of new equipment in the way of desks and blackboards as well as other general school material. If this school were re-opened in all likelihood a fair attendance would be had for at least six months of the year, but as most of the Saanich Indians leave their reserves early in the spring to seek labor in other parts of the Province or the American side, the attendance would be small during the balance of the year.

You will, no doubt, ask why all these children cannot be sent to the residential schools. The answer to this is that it is extremely doubtful if they all could pass the necessary medical examination and, furthermore, the parents have a considerable antipathy against sending their children to the residential schools.

In conclusion, I beg to say the experiment of again opening the Indian Day School on the West Saanich Road might therefore be tried, but there is no use thinking of this unless the Department is prepared to pay a good salary for a good teacher with at least a second class certificate. For, what the Indians like about the public schools is that there are good teachers and the children make excellent progress under their instruction.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF INSPECTOR G. H. BARRY ON HIS
INSPECTION OF THE TSARTLIP INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.
Date of Inspection April 5, 1936.

Name of Teacher: Miss Catherine B. Morry Age 23.

Health: This teacher does not appear to me to be well. She does not appear exactly ill, but she has lost much of her vitality. This is not due to the loss of her father which occurred suddenly about a month ago. This appearance of lassitude was very apparent on the occasion of my previous inspection in December 1935.

In my last two reports I mentioned the neglect of the Primary Grades. The children in the various Sub Grades of Grade 1 have made very little progress during the past year. They have learned some Number Work since my last inspection, but the Reading is very much below the usual standard of the Indian Day Schools. I have of course explained again and again to this teacher how to take up Primary subjects; but for the past two years and particularly for the past year she has shown so little vitality in her work that she is quite unable to teach Primary children with any chance of real success.

I am very sorry that Miss Morry has not been able to continue the good work she did during the first two years here. The past year has been to a great extent just wasted time for the little children. Some progress has been made in Grade 5.

The children attend in rather an irregular manner. This is partly caused by the absence of the Indians at certain seasons on their Seasonal Occupations. Other schools in the Cowichan Agency can keep up a good average attendance where there are just as great difficulties. I am afraid that the falling off in the attendance is a result of lack of interest in the school. The attendance in the December Quarter of 1935 was a little better. The Quarterly attendance averages are as follows:

Quarter ending September 1934 8.8 September 1935 5.53
December 1934 11.2 December 1935 15.1
March 1935 10.21 March 1936 11.74

These attendance averages might be much improved with a teacher here who would visit the homes of the Indians and encourage the children to come to school.
There appears to be many cases of children coming to school late. The teacher does not mark these in the Register. She tells me that perhaps about three children are late on an average daily. This is of course far too high an average and shows a lack of interest on behalf of the pupils.

The very worst feature of this school at the present time is the hopeless lack of control of the younger children. With the exception of the Number Work in Grade 1, which has improved a little, the Primary Grades are in a worse condition than when last reported on by me. The only satisfactory work being done is that in Grade 5.

I am very far from satisfied with the work now being done at this school. I am afraid that I must recommend that the Department make a change of teachers here. An energetic young teacher would make a very great difference at this school. I simply am unable to believe that Miss Morry has any further interest in this school outside the fact that it provides her with a pay cheque each month. From a professional viewpoint though good work was done for some two or three years here, the past year or two years have been largely a complete failure. The decline in the work has been progressive and inclines me to think that the teacher is not well.

It would be best to close this school at the end of May for the summer vacation, and to open it in October with a young energetic teacher, either male or female but for preference the former. This report is being forwarded in time to permit the Department to give the teacher a month's notice and to close the school at the end of May, should they so desire.

EXTRACT FROM LETTER OF INSPECTOR BARRY DATED APRIL 11th, ACCOMPANYING THE ABOVE REPORT.

I hope that this report will reach the Department in time to close the school for the month of June and thus save a little money which will in my opinion only be wasted by keeping the school open till the end of June. I should like the teacher to have a full month's notice should the Department agree with me that a new teacher should be appointed to open school in October. Memorandum:

Honourable Thomas G. Murphy,

With reference to the attached letter from the Secretary of the Victoria branch of the British Columbia Women's Institutes, I have to report that the education of the Indian children of the West Saanich Reserve presents a problem somewhat difficult of solution. An Indian day school could be only partly successful because the Indians do not remain at home from May to October. They gather seaweed in May and June, pick berries in Washington State during the summer, go fishing in the early fall and work in the hop fields until October is well spent.

All healthy children would be welcome at one or other of the Indian residential schools, where splendid facilities are provided; but, as yet, recruiting activity has not been particularly successful, on account of the unwillingness of the parents to send their children to boarding institutions. Of course, some of the children are not physically fit for the intensive training at residential schools.

The Department is seriously considering conducting a winter day school on the reserve, but the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current year is completely assigned. If Commissioner Ditchburn, of Victoria, reports favourably next spring, I intend to make repairs to our old school building, supply the necessary equipment and engage the services of a competent teacher for the winter months. If the school proved successful, it would be continued.

Duncan C. Scott

REPORT ON COWICHAN INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF APRIL, 1943.

All Day Schools closed for the Easter holidays on the 21st, and on visits paid just prior to closing good attendances were general, except in Tsartlip School where the attendance is dropping off gradually. The R.C.M.P. were asked to send a Constable to check up on the Truant children but owing to pressure of other work were unable to do so. It is hoped that we may be able to get a patrol made to the Agency early this month.

R.H. Moore,
Indian Agent.
REPORT FOR THE MONTH OF FEBRUARY 1943.

Owing to the severe cold and deep snow it was considered advisable to close some of the day schools for a few days, especially on the reserves where the children had long distances to walk. School affected were St. Catherines, Kokallah and Tsartlip. The attendance at all schools could be considered satisfactory, although there is still room for improvement, which, in my opinion, will not be obtained without the appointment of a permanent truant officer.

R.H. Moore,
Indian Agent.

Cody, Bishop of Victoria, has taken up with this office the question of the provision of a second classroom at the Tsartlip Indian Day School to relieve overcrowding and also to provide a separate teacher for the higher grades, suggesting the parish hall which is situated a short distance from the school for this purpose.

Thirty-three pupils were enrolled at this little school at the time it was inspected by Inspector Gamble last fall of whom 28 were present. The Inspector's report shows that twenty were in grades 1, 2 and 3 and thirteen in grades 4, 5, 6 and 7.

The matter of the repairs necessary to make the Parish Hall suitable for classroom purposes was referred to Mr. Indian Agent Moore who has estimated the cost at approximately $325.00, which amount does not include the necessary blackboards and fuel.

I understood from Bishop Cody that he would be visiting Ottawa shortly when this matter would be discussed with the Department.

The proposal submitted would in addition to the cost of repairs and equipment, etc., involve the payment of a small monthly rental for the use of the building and the appointment of a second teacher at a salary of $90.00 per month plus bonus.

To Whom It May Concern:

I am writing this letter to state that Sister Mary Corita Kent, teacher in Tsartlip Indian School, Saanichton, B.C., is a member of the California Institute of the Sisters of the Immaculate Heart of Mary of which the undersigned is the Superior General.

I further wish to state that Sister Mary Corita Kent as a member of the Institute of the Sisters of the Immaculate Heart of Mary, cannot, by virtue of the vow of Poverty which she has taken, use the salary which she earns personally. Her salary belongs to the Institute and is deposited with the Procurator of the convent in which she resides. The salary is administered by the Procurator under the direction of the Superior, to provide for the material, physical, and educational needs of the community to which Sister belongs.

The above statements being true, I believe that Sister Mary Corita Kent is according to the Canadian Law exempt from taxes. The law reads, according to a quotation taken from a letter of Mr. Norman Lee, Income Tax Inspector, as follows:

"When a contract is entered into by individual members of a religious institution, by virtue of which remuneration is paid directly to the contracting incumbent and the member receiving such income belongs to a religious institution, order, or community which requires him to take a vow of perpetual Poverty, the income of such a person is not taxable."

I trust that this statement may serve to clarify any doubt in the minds of those concerned as to the identity of Sister Mary Corita Kent and the ground on which she claims tax exemption.

Respectfully yours,

Memorandum:

To: Indian Commissioner for B.C.
From: Inspector of Indian Schools.

I refer to Mr. Neary's letters dated June 4th and 9th, 1947, covering the possibility of converting the California State Teachers' Certificates of Sister M. Socorro, Sister Elizabeth Maria Brady and Sister Mary Ethel to provincial certificates. The Registrar of the Department of Education for B.C., has informed me that his Department will not consider a conversion until the teacher has Canadian citizenship. After that the teacher's academic qualifications would be referred to the University of British Columbia for classification. If the University gave credit for Senior matriculation standing or better, the applicant would then be required to attend one of the Provincial Normal Schools.

I agree with the remarks of Mr. Indian Agent Moore that both Sister Mary Ethel and Sister Elizabeth Maria Brady are doing successful work. These teachers show evidence of sound training, and I rank them among the better teachers in our schools. I would recommend them for Grade 3 classification if the regulation of the Department permitted.

I have not inspected the work of Sister Maria Socorro and cannot comment on it but I note that she has similar professional and academic training.

Memorandum:

MR. HEGY

American School Teaching Certificates

As you are probably aware, we have three excellent members of a religious Order teaching in our Saanich Day Schools.

The question of converting their American junior high school teachers' certificates to Canadian teachers' certificates was referred to Inspector Davey for consultation with the Provincial Department of Education. His answer hereunder is self-explanatory. Our salary regulations in this regard read as follows:-

"Time spent by a duly certificated teacher as a teacher in the public schools in any part of the British Commonwealth, or as an Instructor in a University in any part of the British Commonwealth, shall be regarded as time spent in teaching in the schools of the Indian Affairs Branch, provided that the maximum period of such teaching service to be regarded shall not exceed five years. Such teachers must also have attended one professional or academic session at a Summer School Course recognized by the Indian Affairs Branch in order to qualify for the increments described above in the Regulations for grades of teachers."

You will note that this does not specifically define the actual certificate necessary for classification on our schedule. Elsewhere in the Bulletin we have said that special consideration would be necessary for teachers holding English and other teaching certificates.

I would appreciate hearing your views upon this problem.

Dear Mr. Neary,

I am addressing this letter to you as last year's acknowledgment of my letters was signed by you. The purpose of today's letter is to identify Sister M. Ethel Swain, teacher at Tsartlip Indian School, Saanichon, B.C. that she may claim tax exemption.

I wish to state that Sister M. Ethel Swain is a member of the California Institute of the Sisters of the Immaculate Heart of Mary of which the undersigned is the Superior General.

Furthermore, I wish to state that Sister M. Ethel Swain as a member of the Institute of the Sisters of the Immaculate Heart of Mary, cannot by virtue of the vow of Poverty which she has taken, use the salary which she earns personally. Her salary belongs to the Institute and is deposited with the Procurator of the convent in which she resides. The salary is administered by the Procurator under the direction of the Superior, to provide for the material, physical, and educational needs of the community to which Sister belongs.

The above statements being true, I believe that Sister M. Ethel Swain is, according to the Canadian Law, exempt from taxes. The law reads, according to a quotation taken from a letter of Mr. Norman Lee, Income Tax Inspector, as follows:

"When a contract is entered into by an individual member of a religious institution, by virtue of which remuneration is paid directly to the contracting incumbent and the member receiving such income belongs to a religious institution, order, or community which requires him to take a vow of perpetual Poverty, the income of such a person is not taxable."

I trust that this statement may serve to clarify any doubts in the minds of those concerned as to the identity of Sister M. Ethel Swain and the ground on which she claims tax exemption.

Respectfully yours,

Sister M. Eucharis, Superior General

With reference to my remarks under this heading in the report on this school dated April 15th, 1932, I notice that the pump recommended has not been supplied nor is the floor of the schoolroom being kept clean as suggested. I do not understand why money is wasted in having a well dug and then no simple method of making use of the water for the school supplied. This partial carrying out of my recommendations is of course quite useless to the school children and results in an expenditure of Public Funds that could not possibly be justified.

The toilets are in fairly clean condition. I noticed paper flying about the vicinity of the boys' toilet, the seat of which should be kept dry. Chloride of lime will be needed during the summer. I asked the teacher to keep these toilets under constant inspection.
Ottawa, April 11, 1933.

Sir:

Mr. Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools, in a report on his recent visit to the Tsartlip Indian Day School, states that no pump was installed in the well which was dug last year, and that this partial carrying out of the work in connection with the well is quite useless to the school children and has resulted in an expenditure of public funds that cannot be justified.

The Department understands that this well was completed early last summer. If a pump has not yet been installed, it will be necessary to supply same, and I have to request that you will furnish an estimate of the cost of supplying and installing a pump and any pipe, etc., required. This matter should receive your prompt attention, as it would appear that this well is useless without pumping facilities.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, December 5, 1933.

Sir:

The Department has just received Inspector Barry's report regarding his visit to the Tsartlip Indian Day School on the 17th ultimo. The Inspector states that the floor is in a very dirty state and that the teacher informed him that it is difficult to sweep, as the dust flies about the room. Mr. Barry suggests that the floor should be washed at least once a month or that it should be oiled and Dustbane used daily in sweeping.

You will remember that this matter was brought to your attention by official letter of April 27, 1932. Subsequently you forwarded a voucher for $3.00 for labour in washing, cleaning and oiling the floor. Apparently the floor was cleaned at that time but, as mentioned in the first paragraph of this letter, the Inspector considers that it again requires attention. I would point out that payment of $2.50 a month is made to the teacher for janitor services. It is considered that, from this amount, she should expend sufficient to have the floor washed regularly.

You may purchase a small supply of Dustbane to be used for sweeping.

The Department trusts that you will give this matter your immediate attention, in order that there may be no further complaint. You should also advise the Department when you have taken action in the matter.

Mr. Perry is being authorized to purchase and forward to the school the three new desks recommended by the Inspector.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Form No. 101
Sir,

On visiting the Tsartlip Indian Day School yesterday, I found that the well was completely dry, as were also all the wells in the vicinity, with the result that there was no water available for the children to drink.

I went over the situation with Reverend Father Lemmens, and some of the Indians, and we came to the conclusion that the only thing to be done was to deepen the present well, to try to get water.

Our reason for concluding this was, that there was an old Indian well in the vicinity which they claim never did dry up, but is now filled in, and it was deeper than the school well.

I endeavored to get a price on doing the work from the Indians, but none of them would contract, as we will have to go through rotten rock, and they can not tell how hard it is, and what amount of powder will be required.

I would like to get permission to deepen this well, another ten feet if necessary, and have the work done by the Indians by day labour. Reverend Father Lemmens, will undertake to supervise the work. I would estimate that if we have to go down ten feet that it will cost at least $50.00.

Your obedient servant,

H. Graham

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA.
EX'D.

Ottawa,
October 5, 1937.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of September 24th, you may expend an amount not exceeding Fifty dollars ($50.00) in deepening the well at the Tsartlip Indian Day School.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

H. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Dear Sir:

Please refer to your letter of July 31st last, File No. 152-14-5 relative to the report of Inspector Barry on the Tsartlip Day School. I did not reply to that letter owing to the fact that just the day before your letter was received I wrote Major MacKay recommending the kind of a heater that would be suitable for the school, the cost of which would be $32.00 wholesale, F.O.B. Victoria. The present heater is most unsuitable for this, or any other, school building.

I also asked in the same letter for a small grant of $15.00 to erect playground equipment, consisting of swings, teeter-totters & basketball boards & hoop.

I spoke to the Commissioner afterwards about the letter and he said that he sent on my letter to Ottawa with his recommendations. However, to date no authority has been received to purchase the heater neither have I received the necessary authority for the playground equipment.

While on the Tsartlip School question I would respectfully direct your attention to my letter of July 4th last with attached requisition for school supplies for this school, some of which were authorised in Mr Hoey's letter of July 15th. File # 152-14-5. However, a soft-ball and two bats were not authorised and I would respectfully ask that I be given authority to purchase these locally.

Kindly take the various matters mentioned above into consideration and advise as soon as conveniently possible.

Your obedient servant;

The Secretary;

Ottawa.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Sir:-

With further reference to my report for the month of October on the Tsartlip School, I wish to submit a proposal to the Department for consideration which I feel would be of direct benefit to the Indian children and would, I think, help to assure a more regular attendance as well as greater punctuality at this School.

The large majority of the children attending this school come from very poor class families, whose parents are either on relief all the time or during the winter months, the result being that they (the children) are none too well nourished and seldom have anything hot for their mid-day meal when they go home. If the Department would be kind enough to allow a small monthly grant for cocoa, milk and sugar amounting to $5.00 I am sure that it would be a great blessing to these children, especially some of those who take their lunch—such as it is—to School. While some of the others who go home for their lunch, and don't get much, could take what little they do get to school and augment it with Cocoa. This will also mean that 26 enamel cups and half a dozen tea spoons should be supplied which the teacher could procure very reasonable at the 15¢ store in Victoria.

If the Department can see their way clear to approve of this suggestion, I will then try a further step which I hope will eventually prove a success, and that is to have each child bring a couple of raw potatoes and some raw vegetables each day to school which could be prepared and cooked by the bigger girls under the supervision of the teacher and then divided up among the children in the form of a hot vegetable dinner at noon. This I feel would be a distinct benefit to the children and would not take any of the responsibility of caring and feeding the children away from the parents or guardians. Your earnest and sympathetic consideration is respectfully requested to the above suggestion and an early reply to the second paragraph of this letter.

The Secretary;
Indian Affairs Branch.
Mines & Resources.
Ottawa.

Your obedient servant;

(R.H.Moore)
